TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to that diatribe with a great degree of interest. I could not help recalling, having been here for a few years, that we are in the Senate; we are not taking part in a school debating society. The school debating society technique of Senator Puplick is to grab every quotation he can find from various people, throw them all together and read them out to the Senate. Not once in his speech was there any idea of conceptual issues relating to science policy, not once in that speech was there any idea of what the Government's policies have been in relation to the policies of previous governments, and not once in that speech was there any regard for facts as distinct from fiction.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Government is going to bring down a science policy statement next week. Senator Puplick also knows that. I knew that this speech would be made today, thrown together by the Opposition at the last moment so that it could say when the Government's statement was brought down, `We provoked all of that. We raised all these issues last week. What a vigorous Opposition we are'. That is the purpose of this so-called matter of public importance today. I have often accused the Liberals of being the 1960s show. Their ideas and minds are firmly rooted in the 1960s and stuck there, regurgitating in a whole range of policy areas the things they stood for in the 1960s. Senator Puplick is said to be one of the trendies of the Liberal Party, but he is doing that again today.

Let me address the basic problem which this Government had to face when it came to office: the worst record in research and development in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development after 29 out of 30 years of Liberal Government in this country. That is the issue we had to address when we came into government in 1983 following the last Budget of those opposite in 1982. We had a situation in which people complained all the time about various issues.

Senator Puplick has been at it again today. Japan, he says, has an enormous record in research funding. Does Senator Puplick not know that 80 per cent of Japanese research funding is conducted by the private sector? Does he not know that in Australia 70 per cent of research funding is paid for by the public sector and that that figure was 80 per cent when the coalition was in office? Does Senator Puplick not understand those figures? Does he not understand that the very fact of commitment to private sector research in Japan has been a great strength to the Japanese economy, whereas we drifted along for 29 years under Liberal governments with nothing being done about these issues? I thought the philosophy of a Liberal party was to lay stress upon the importance of the private sector in dealing with all these issues. Did the Liberal Party ever lay stress on the importance of the private sector in dealing with issues of science and technology in this country? Not at all. It allowed the general level of funding for research and development to decline in those 29 years of government, including the seven years of Fraser Government, the most crucial period of neglect in Australia's history. It allowed all of that to happen and it left it all on the plate of the Hawke Government when it came to power.

Senator Archer asked me, for example, whether he could table a document from the National Health and Medical Research Council in relation to medical research in Australia. When the honourable senator uses that document he ought to get up and tell the Senate about the increase under this Government in research and development funds available to medical research in Australia. Let him get up and tell us that rather than him give us the annual whinge from medical researchers about research funding. He should tell us what the increase has been when he uses that document in a speech. I hope he does not blush when he says it. He ought to blush when he compares the increase of research funding for medical research with what happened in the days of his Government.

Throughout Senator Puplick's speech he dealt lightly with the truth on all of these issues. He said research funds had been cut by 32 per cent in cumulative terms. Where does he get that figure from? I think he gets it from the Opposition spokesman on science. What a source to go to if one wanted to get an accurate figure on any of these issues! Perhaps he gets it from the Opposition spokesman on education, who keeps talking about the Department of Science, which was abolished two years ago, who keeps talking about research funding in universities as if nothing had happened in the last 10 years. Perhaps he gets it from one of those two shadow Ministers, the people who would be over here-God help the country-if the misfortune ever came about that those opposite were elected to government. There were crass inaccuracies in much of the material which was regurgitated by Senator Puplick in his speech today. It was a most discreditable effort.

Let us look at the question of Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation funding, to which Senator Puplick gave some attention in the course of his remarks. CSIRO's budget has not been cut by 32 per cent, as Senator Puplick alleged, or by 28 per cent over the past five years, as some people have claimed. It is true that the Government appropriations for CSIRO have been reduced by 17 per cent over that period, but the overall budget of CSIRO has been reduced by only 7.5 per cent. Why? This Government was confronted with a situation where 80 per cent of research was being done in Australia in the public sector, paid for by the taxpayers. In countries such as Japan and in various European countries almost 80 per cent of research and development was being done by the private sector and paid for by the private sector.

We say that in Australia the balance should be shifted more towards a balance between taxpayer-funded research and development and private-sector funded research and development. That is deliberate government policy. We have asked CSIRO to earn 30 per cent of its earnings from private industry. The Opposition did nothing about that for 30 years and the CSIRO languished because of it. We have asked CSIRO to earn 30 per cent from outside and have permitted it to retain the earnings it makes from outside. That is a low proportion, compared with what the great international research institutes require in respect of their budgets. It is only 30 per cent. We think that is about the right figure, in the Australian context, because the CSIRO has very important core capability roles in terms of the agricultural sector, the environment, meteorology and things of that kind. We have embarked on a deliberate strategy. Senator Puplick does not seem to understand that.

Secondly, Senator Puplick talked about a reduction in funds for CSIRO. That reflects a reduction from a capital works budget for major projects such as the Australian Telescope, at a cost of $50m, and the Clayton Material Science Laboratory, at a cost of $148m. The Animal Health Laboratory in Geelong is a monument to the sorts of things which Senator Puplick would do if he ever became Minister. The Fraser Government did that. It cost $50m. Can Senator Teague get anybody to get up and say that that was a good spending decision? These were the things which money was spent on, and properly so in respect of the first two projects I mentioned. That is where the comparison is made. Big sums of money were spent by the previous Government on these projects and of course the CSIRO's funding has declined, particularly in capital funding, but also in recurrent funding, for the reasons I have given.

Senator Puplick also made a point about basic and applied research. It was a silly point. Probably one of the best basic researchers in Australia at present is also a very distinguished applied researcher. There is a continuum between basic and applied research, and to create an artificial argument between the two is rather ridiculous. I want to make a few more information points in the time available to me in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long is Wran going to last?

—Well, Senator Teague asked that when Mr Wran was in government. He was always asking, `How long is Wran going to last?'. Those opposite put up their best and their brightest and they got knocked over all the time. He will probably last a while.
—He just got out in time.

—I knew Senator Boswell would come in with the brown paper bags. The fact is that government funding of research and development as a proportion of GDP is higher in Australia now than in Japan, Canada, Belgium, Switzerland and Italy. Total research and development expenditure in this country is up 39 per cent in real terms since 1981-82. Consult any of the international journals, Senator Archer, if you speak in this debate. As a share of gross domestic product, research and development expenditure has grown from 1 per cent to 1.25 per cent since this Government came to office. That is not good enough, but it is better than it was in all the time those opposite were in government. Business expenditure on research and development has doubled between 1981-82 and 1986-87 and is continuing to rise. Business spent $1,200m on research and development in Australia last year. None of these things was mentioned or acknowledged by Senator Puplick. Judging by the tone of his remarks, I would not think that he even knew about them. He quoted some scientist who said that there is a great brain drain of scientists out of Australia. The fact is that there have been 12,500 new research and development positions created in Australia between 1981-82 and 1986-87, largely in the private sector and in education institutions. There has been a net gain in the number of scientists, engineers and so on over the past five years. It is true that many young scientists go overseas. They always have, and 80 or 90 per cent of them leaving Australia come back. They leave with the intention of coming back, and that has always been so.
—They need to go over there and have a look.

—Of course they do. Most young scientists, whether they be Americans, Australians, French or whatever, want international experience. That is proper because science is an international community. That is natural and is quite consistent with the career path of young scientists who need international experience.
—But morale in CSIRO is very low.

—Senator Teague interjects about the morale in CSIRO. That organisation is going through a period of restructuring as a result of an inquiry which this Government commissioned. It is a restructuring which the Government thought should take place, and is the most major restructuring of its kind in the 63-year history of its organisation. It had to undergo that, as many other sectors of the Australian economy have had to undergo restructuring and change. That has led to some difficulties in the management of CSIRO. There have been many spokesmen from all parts of CSIRO talking about these things, and I understand that, but it is part of a deliberate strategy. CSIRO has to be the best of its kind in the world, if together we can make it so. That is why government is committed to better equipment for CSIRO and similarly to better equipment in the universities.
—When?

—We will be making a statement about some of these issues next week. When we discuss these issues, let us not be like Senator Puplick who comes in here and sounds as though any scientist who writes a letter to a newspaper, any scientist who writes a letter to Senator Puplick, any scientist who makes a bit of noise on a television program would, if Senator Puplick were the Minister, immediately receive a cheque in the post saying `Dear Professor Chatterton, we know you are aggrieved about funding for science and we are sending you a cheque for $25m by return mail'. That is Senator Puplick's attitude when he comes in here and thinks that the Government has these sorts of responsibilities. He feels that the Government must respond to all these requests wherever they come from, and from whatever section of the community, by saying `Cheque in the post by return mail. We are an efficient government. We will show you how to handle these people'. That was the tone of Senator Puplick's speech: `I have got all these letters, all these articles in newspapers, showing that people are a bit concerned about change and about one thing and another. SPEECH.PARA: That is not the style of this Government. The style of this Government in respect of these matters is to recognise that we have been stringent with these organisations. We regret that. The style of this Government is also to see that these organisations are modern, progressive and capable of responding flexibly-an organisation like the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research capable of responding to the needs of Australian industry whether in the primary, manufacturing or service sectors; capable of reacting to and interacting with industry in a way which never happened in this country before. People come along with their complaints, like `We invented the black box in Australia. What happened to it? It went overseas'. `We invented this or that in Australia. What happened to it? It went overseas'. That is their complaint. That all happened in the period of government of those opposite because they did nothing about these issues of producing interaction between industries and scientific organisations.

When some scientists hear these sorts of remarks from somebody like me, they say, `He is unrepentant. He wants us all to be wearing blue overalls and working out there in industry'. That sort of talk is a lot of bunkum. All I am saying is that there has to be better reaction and interaction between government and scientific organisations and industry. It is no good listening to every second wimp who writes a letter to the newspaper because he is particularly aggrieved about a particular matter. One has to have a strategy and a policy for these things. The strategy and the policy is to help people to improve the performance as much as we can within proper economic responsibility by improving the equipment, the conditions, the interactions and the capacity for exchange; by increasing the critical mass of scientists working in Australia; and by helping them to relate better to international science and what is going on here. By doing all these things we shall encourage an environment in which science can grow and develop in this country consistent, among other things, with the economic needs of this country.

Senator Puplick comes into this chamber and says that there are fewer students doing science as part of the higher school certificate now than there were 20 years ago. That is absolutely right. The number of students doing physics as part of the HSC has been declining by one per cent a year for 20 years. That is a tragedy. One cannot turn that around overnight. One can only do it by making a positive and constructive environment, and to reach that environment for science one has to have change. One cannot walk away from that and again put on the 1960s show of the Liberal Party. One cannot go through all the stuff of doing nothing for 20 years and leaving a subsequent government in the sort of mess in which those opposite left us in connection with this issue, as on every other issue they failed to face up to in their years of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this matter of public importance. SPEECH.PARA: I take Senator Button's point that the question we are debating this afternoon is much more serious than simply saying that if we observe an area of need and throw money at it, somehow we will get a scientific result. One can illustrate the point that Senator Button was making by referring to the 1987-88 report of the Australian Science and Technology Council which observes that 1.33 per cent of gross domestic product went into research and development in 1968-69, that the percentage fell progressively until 1978 through to 1982 when it was only one per cent, and that since then it has risen marginally to 1.16 per cent in 1985-86. The percentage is still below what it was in 1968-69 but certainly it has increased since the years of the Fraser Government. The problem is not just one that concerns Senator Button and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). This Government as a whole has indicated a clear anti-intellectual and anti-science bias. I believe that it has also shown a complete and utter misunderstanding of the role and function of science and research in society.

The Hawke Government is about to turn around its support and I believe that this will be presaged in a statement which will be made next Monday. It is quite clear from the evidence that it is not turning around its basic philosophy. It has not suddenly discovered an understanding of the role and function of science and society. The Government has discovered that there are votes out there in the area of science and research funding. It is turning itself around for purely political reasons because the course it has been following for the last six years has been proven to be politically unpopular. As I indicated, I find that there is very little to choose between the Government and the Opposition.

In terms of turning around for political reasons, one need only reflect on the urgency motion on the Antarctic which Senator Vallentine put up in the Senate barely a fortnight ago. The Opposition amended and thereby rejected the thrust of Senator Vallentine's motion to protect and preserve the Antarctic as a conservation zone. The Government and the Opposition voted together in support of that amendment. Now, barely a fortnight later, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) says that he will move to protect the Antarctic. We find precisely the same political duplicity on the part of the Government in relation to science funding and science support.

Minister Jones, who is mentioned in this matter of public importance, is clearly at odds with the Government over science policy. For instance, I note that Mr Jones published the book Sleepers Wake shortly before this Government came into office. One of the first actions of the Hawke Government was to call a National Economic Summit Conference. Mr Jones sought to read a paper which would have clearly outlined the sorts of philosophies that come through Sleepers Wake. Mr Hawke refused Mr Jones permission to read his paper to the National Economic Summit Conference on the grounds that he did not want industry to hear a message which would have been too disturbing. At the Australian Labor Party conference in Hobart in 1984 Mr Jones described the Hawke Government's science policy as `intellectual vandalism'. He said that the Government should `reject the slot machine approach to research funding'. It is reported that when that statement was made Mr Hawke walked out of the conference.

In 1985 Mr Jones was invited to lead discussions at a seven-nation conference on technology in Ottawa. Mr Hawke refused Mr Jones permission to attend that conference. I understand that Mr Jones paid for his own fare to Ottawa. He travelled second class while the head of his Department travelled first class to the same conference. As recently as 11 March this year, in an article in the Courier-Mail, Mr Jones stated:
I have to confess not being interested in sport, which I see as a major political disability. If I could talk football, I'd have been in the inner Cabinet.

The problem is not just with Mr Jones or Senator Button, as outlined in the matter of public importance. There is a lack of understanding throughout the whole of the Hawke Ministry which extends to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Senator Button, Senator Walsh and Senator Cook. I repeat: I believe that they have a complete lack of understanding of the role of science and research in society and that attitude really needs to be turned around. As I have indicated, I find that same attitude is held by most members of the Opposition.

There is very little experience in either this chamber or the other chamber in actual research. Out of the 224 members of the House of Representatives and the Senate, I think only three people have any actual practical research experience. I have said that there is little difference between the Government and the Opposition. Quite clearly, both would direct research through a competitive market system. As I have indicated, the market system is not directed towards the goals of society; it is directed towards those things which are economically profitable in the short run for those who control the market, and that is certainly not the whole of society. At a very early age, Dr Ferrington published 30 papers in international journals. This scientist, who has presented another 30 papers to scientific societies, has had strong support from his supervisor, Professor Rowe. Dr Ferrington is doing important work in understanding the nervous system and furthering the knowledge of chronic pain. However, he is quite incapable of surviving on his income of $30,000 a year and has recently given up his job in scientific research to become a computer programmer. It should be noted that, in the market-driven system, a computer programmer gets $60,000 a year for a 40-hour week. That is the sort of direction that our research work will take if we continue to believe that we can allow the private market profit-oriented system to direct the goals to which that research effort should be bent.

The Government, quite clearly, wants to cut back direct government funding. It has expected the private sector to pick up some 30 per cent of that research funding with respect to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and the universities. As I have said-I think it must be repeated-that is the wrong direction to take if we want science to be properly integrated into society, if we want science to be directed towards proper socially determined goals and not merely towards those things which result in short term profitability.

I hate to use the words `pure research', but certainly there is a distinction between long term research which is not intentionally directed towards application and those developmental types of activities which are clearly directed towards an application with the hope of profit at the other end. As Senator Puplick pointed out, that type of pure research is very often of a long term nature and does not necessarily produce, even in the long term, results which can be applied and which will be turned to profit. But occasionally it is, and it is that long term research which very often causes the major changes in technology which become extremely profitable.

In that research there is also an element of serendipity. One can point to the development of the transistor which led to an enormous shift in the way research work is done. It came out of pure research which at the time was in no sense directed towards an application. The Watson-Crick model of DNA, the understanding of the structure of DNA, which led to an enormous explosion in practically applied research, initially was not in any way directed towards that sort of research. In terms of serendipity, I point also to the discovery of superconductivity. If cold fusion, which has been in the papers a lot recently, turns out to be a valid observation, it is another example of serendipity, not the sort of result that comes from the directed research by industry.

Science is of enormous value to society. The understanding of the world in which we live is a culturally enriching experience and that has been downplayed by the Government. To repeat the words of Barry Jones, `Science is not a slot machine'. We do not simply put in so much money, pull a lever, and within three years get out a result that we can apply in some development which will be known to be profitable. Some areas of research will never be funded by private industry. I refer, for example, to the work on soil conservation which is vitally important to this country, and to the work on biological control of pests and so on. By and large, that sort of research would be inimical to the interests of chemical companies and they are not likely to fund it. It is vital that that research be funded by government. If the Government directs society towards competitive greed-it is the motive that it talks about constantly-we will not have the young going into those areas of research which are of social benefit. The young will go into those areas in which there are quick returns, high incomes and the potential to acquire a large number of material goodies as quickly as possible.

Dr Smiles, the head of the CSIRO Division of Soils, just recently pointed out that some $600m-worth of nutrients are lost to Australia each year from agricultural production which is exported. Last week he told me that what worried him was that the $600m did not occur anywhere in the national accounts. It does not occur in the national accounts because neither the Government nor the Opposition keeps the equivalent of a capital national account in which that money might occur. Again, we find a gross directed type of economics in both the Government and the Opposition, which fail to take account of these things and which therefore fail to put a proper value on them. The public perception of the value of science is diminishing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the appalling lack of attention the Government has given to science funding in Australia and particularly the roles the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, have played in this deterioration. Senator Puplick has already very well led this debate for the Opposition and made some very pertinent points. The chronic neglect and deterioration in the financial, capital and human resources within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) is a stinging indictment on this Government. The Government's view of life goes no further than each successive election and it has carried on in this manner for the past six years. Its entire range of policies reflect this blinkered vision for Australia, but no more so than in the area of research funding.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's attacks on CSIRO are not new, as has already been mentioned today. It has been nibbling away at research funding for years, hoping no-one will notice. It most probably presumed that scientists, being a dedicated group, would accept the restrictions and give their time and resources freely to allow their work to continue, as many have done. But this year the scientific community has said, `No more'. Scientists have at last dared to speak up and out against what has amounted to a betrayal of their profession, led in no small measure by the CSIRO Chairman, Neville Wran, the former Premier of New South Wales. The CSIRO scientists have felt betrayed because, in their hour of need, when they might have expected their Chairman to come to their aid and to speak out on their behalf, he remained absolutely mute.

Senator Puplick has already outlined the savage attacks that have been made on industry research and other areas of research. Today, I highlight the damage the Government has done to the rural sector. I do not need to remind the Senate that it is the rural sector that provides our much needed export income. It is the rural sector that is expected to continue this role for years to come. Senator Button can say and do all he likes about manufacturing in this country, but we know the futility of his words. Our future does not lie in manufacturing exports; it lies with the rural sector, the primary industry sector. Senator Button and Mr Wran would do well to remember that when they next try to apply the knife to rural research.

Lest it be thought that this is a beat-up by the Opposition and a few disgruntled scientists, as Senator Button has said it is, we should hear what others think about the Government's approach to research funding. A leading rural writer, Julian Cribb, in the Weekend Australian last October said:
Australian science has entered a new Dark Age in which its funds, community support, staffing, physical resources and scientific morale are being whittled relentlessly away.
Australia's status as a scientific progressive nation shrinks with each international comparison-
Senator Puplick has already mentioned that-
the latest one disclosed our support for science to be poorer than 15 other western nations-including Finland, Austria, the Netherlands, Italy and Switzerland.

The hidden message is that for decades to come Australia will be paying for other people's technology. Instead of earning income from research, we'll be blowing it, with inescapable consequences for our overseas debt and living standards.

The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, would be concerned about those things. Julian Cribb, to back up his comments, lists a veritable who's who of Australian scientists who have moved their work overseas where, they say, they are appreciated and paid for what they do. Among them are Dr Tony Fischer, pioneer of Australia's conservation tillage research effort, now in Mexico working on world wheat research, and professor Peter Gresshoff, the CSIRO scientist who pioneered the super soy bean, who is now in the United States. He visited our area a few years ago to tell us about the super soy bean. They have left because of higher salaries and research funding three or four times greater than that available here. Of more importance is the assurance that they will be able to complete their work because of adequate funding and sufficient technical backup. The Bulletin writer David Barnett is another who has attacked the cutbacks to CSIRO. Nearly 18 months ago, he wrote:
The windback in research is occurring at a time which is increasingly critical for the major primary industries, because of environmental and animal welfare concerns.

Australia exports insect-free wheat because of a clever use of pesticides. It may in due course have to export wheat which is pesticide-free as well as insect-free. Meat exports have had problems. Irrigation has produced massive salinity problems in the Murray Basin. Concern about chemicals points in the direction of what has been a major area of CSIRO activity, the search for natural predators and enemies of exotic weeds and pests: myxomatosis for rabbits, insects which eat Paterson's curse, Salvinia and other unwanted plants.
The Canberra Times in February this year claimed that Australia was sliding into mediocrity in science funding. Last November it was even more scathing when it said:

If this shameful axing of science and engineering in Australia continues, in the long term the nation's industry will suffer, its income will fall and so will taxes. And then there will be even less money for the Government to buy votes with.

That is probably a good thing for Senator Walsh to remember. The National Farmers Federation President, John Allwright, claims that science policy in Australia is in disarray, wandering aimlessly from fad to fashion. He said:
It is apparent that the disregard for the importance of research reaches right to the highest levels of government-and that is a national disgrace.

That is what he told the National Science Forum in Canberra recently. His concern is completely understandable. Australian farmers, even some of those who live near Senator Walsh, are considered to be among the most efficient and productive in the world. They have reached that level, however, only with the help of the scientific community. Rural industries have always been strong supporters of CSIRO research, and their investment has returned some handsome dividends, such as better yielding crops and plants, faster growing animals and greater control of pests and diseases.

Let me give some examples. The blowfly is the scourge of the Australian bush. CSIRO scientists developed a dung beetle-which, by the way, is working very well this year-suitable for Australian conditions that would eat cattle dung, which is the breeding ground for the fly. This work was done in Canberra by the Australian National University John Curtin School of Medical Research, which has made enormous advances in embryo technology in cattle and has gone on to increase knowledge in in vitro fertilisation technology. This has enabled Australia to remain at the forefront of breeding; has allowed imports of genetically superior cattle; and, as my colleague Senator Archer, an eminent former breeder of limousin cattle, would know-he will follow me in this debate-has allowed frozen cattle embryos into this country without exposing the industry to potential disease risks.

I have been fortunate to visit the CSIRO animal production unit at Prospect in Sydney where Dr Trevor Scott headed a team of dedicated scientists looking at automated defleecing of sheep, at immunology solutions and at parasitic control. Sadly, Dr Trevor Scott is a casualty of this Government. Much has been said and written about the CSIRO's loss of Dr Scott. He felt that it was impossible to continue to lead his team under ever-worsening conditions, on less and less funding and with restrictions on equipment and vital research projects.

In recent weeks, much publicity has been given to joint State-Federal initiatives in soil conservation. Senator Cook spoke about that today. As a long-time crusader for the cause of soil conservation, I welcome and applaud those initiatives, but I am cynical enough to question the sincerity of these announcements when, at the same time, we are losing more than $600m annually in soil erosion and CSIRO scientists with expertise in this area are being sacked and their laboratories closed down. That is a question I should like Senator Cook to answer later during this Parliament.

The Australian fishing industry is similarly under threat and with it are the research projects and scientific staff that would help the industry survive through to the next century. The Government has attacked the purse strings of CSIRO. It has done this systematically for years without apparent objection from the community and, to a large extent, from the scientists themselves. But the rot has gone on for too long and has now penetrated the core of research in this country. The scientific staff themselves are now realising the overwhelming hopelessness of their situation.

A survey done recently among scientists at the Australian National University and CSIRO had alarming results-results that ought to concern very much the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and, indeed, the Minister for Industry, Technology, and Commerce (Senator Button), whose sensitivity in this area could be regarded as a bull in a china shop approach. The results showed that 78 per cent of scientists perceive their career prospects as poor, and a total of 49 per cent would be prepared to leave Australian research. They are alarming figures. Of more significance is the age structure of scientists at places such as CSIRO. This Government is programming a scientific drought for the years ahead. Senator Button has claimed that scientists have never had it so good. Of course, that is a statement that Whitlam made before he lost government, which was a long time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Senator Walsh today on roads?

—Of course, Senator Walsh said that we have never had the roads so good, or that the roads have never been so good. Instead of trying to understand and listen to scientific community grievances, Senator Button has bashed them over the head with the big stick approach. He has claimed that 12,500 new scientist jobs were created between 1982 and 1986, but this would be equal to nearly three CSIROs or three defence science and technology institutes. The numbers simply are not there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government says, in its defence, that it is not its fault that science funding is at its lowest percentage of gross domestic product for 10 years at 0.646 per cent. It says that it is the fault of industry and that industry should be paying more. That may be so, but we cannot cut funding off one day and expect someone else to pick it up the next. Another factor that has been forgotten is that many Australian companies-in fact, most-are too small to have a viable research capacity. This Government has attacked industry for its lack of contribution and in some cases that criticism is warranted, but it has also attacked scientists, and that is decidedly the wrong approach.

Senator Button said in his speech today that the style of this Government is to recognise that we have been very stringent. I would say that that would be pretty right. But he also said that the Government had been capable of responding to industry. He said `bunkum' to some of the statements made by Senator Puplick. I say `bunkum' to some of Senator Button's statements. He said that the strategy and policy are to improve performance, equipment and interaction, but I can tell him that the morale of the scientific community is very low. I say, `Bunkum to Button', and that is not bunkum.

Rural industry has paid its fair share of the bill as far as the scientific community is concerned. The Australian Special Rural Research Council seeks parallel funding from industry for its projects. During 1987-88 it supported 154 research projects, contributing $3.1m to them. In 1988-89 the Council will contribute $3m to 170 projects with a further $1.7m coming from industry. The wheat, wool, sheepmeat, beef, poultry, pig and grain industries all support research through levies on growers, and it is those industries that will pull this country out of its foreign debt crisis. Take away their support in terms of rural scientific research and this country is condemned to permanent economic chaos. The Government is aware of the difficulties that it has created, although I wonder about that after listening to Senator Button today. Various scientific bodies have provided sound documented proof of their claims, but the Government continues to turn a deaf ear to the scientific community. It cannot continue to do so and it must not. I have much pleasure in supporting Senator Puplick, as I know Senator Archer will shortly, in putting forward a matter of public importance in the following terms:

The failure of the Ministers responsible for science policy and funding, in particular Senator Button and Mr Jones, and the failure of the Chairman of the CSIRO, Mr Neville Wran, to give adequate support and leadership to either the CSIRO or to the Australian scientific community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has taken a fairly unhealthy turn, not so much in the chamber today as in the community at large. Senator Puplick, of course, disappointed me again. Speaking on behalf of the Opposition, Senator Puplick, in initiating this debate, was prepared, in his usual Shakespearian way, to make one or two rather poetic statements about the future of science in this country and to slam together some hastily cobbled up facts, and then to depart the Shakespearian stage that he created-exeunt, I would say, to the left or to the right. It is a bit difficult for Senator Puplick nowadays to work out whether he is going out through the left or out through the right after the drubbing that his colleague Senator Bishop gave him.

SPEECH.PARA: It was unfortunate that Senator Puplick should, in this place, have simply gone off on what was a fairly erratic approach towards what is a very real problem in Australia at the moment, that is, the question of just how we promote science not only in terms of what is applied in the business community and to the benefit of the community at large but also in terms of how we sell the importance of science to the whole community. I will come to that issue at a later stage in my speech. In the end, we are not just talking about what a government can do about science and what a government can do about the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). We are talking about a partnership between government, the scientific community and the business community so that the full benefits of the work that Australians do with regard to science is felt right across the board.

Senator Puplick, somewhere in that Shakespearian attack on the Government managed to find time to bring up one or two specific complaints. I address some of those now. His first complaint was that there was a failure by the Government to make the CSIRO commercially active and viable. One only has to look at the record of this Government compared with that of previous Liberal governments. We have taken one simple initiative which was so simple that I wonder why, for example, it was never done by previous Liberal governments. I guess it was basically because they were conservative. They talk about, for example, exposing Australia to the marketplace. We hear that so often from their party room. Of course it causes all sorts of damage in their party room when they are forced to work out the difference between their theory and their practice and where they get their votes. Nevertheless, for people who talk about marketplace economics and about the role of the market in changing what we do in politics in this country particularly with regard to the economic reorganisation of Australia, they seem to be a long way off the mark when it comes to science. We as a government introduced the approach that at least one-third of the budget of the CSIRO should be brought in from external sources, that is, basically selling its skills in the marketplace particularly to Australian business and to businesses that have an export orientation.

That approach in itself, of course, has affected the funding of the CSIRO, particularly if we take out some of the major capital works programs that have been completed. The funding of the CSIRO, on the face of it, has gone down. But, if we take out those capital works and if we take out a number of other factors, we find that the funding drop has been about 7 per cent once we take into account the return that the CSIRO is getting now from some of its commercial activities. That an institution which has been around for 63 years should be forced to go out into the marketplace and to say, `We have special skills that are valuable to the Australian community, particularly the business community', is a healthy sign. If it was my choice as the responsible Minister, I would increase that percentage, probably close to half, which would be more in line with what is being done overseas. Australia being what it is-a country that has a small population spread out over a large geographical area-we must accept that governments probably have to do a little more in certain areas than they would in other countries. Nevertheless, that proposition that the CSIRO should fund itself, at least to the extent of one-third, through externally generated sources, is the most appropriate decision that this Government has made with regard to the CSIRO since I have been in this Parliament.

The results, of course, are simple to see. There are approximately 20 equity arrangements that the CSIRO has entered into with private enterprise. Some of these arrangements will strike difficulties. If one is going out onto the threshold of business activity if one is doing something different, if one is doing something that can promise benefits further down the line if one is challenging the frontiers of business activity and applied science, one will make some mistakes. Any parliament that sits here and says, `Let's play it safe' is in fact returning to that 1960s approach that we took across the whole economy when we said, `Let's play it safe. Let's put up tariffs if our industries are in trouble. Let's not worry about exports because they happen to be more difficult to achieve. Let's import what we need. Let's sell our patents overseas so that major companies can buy those patents and then we have our ideas exported back to us'. That was the approach we took. We said, `Let's through a quota system limit competitive goods from foreign countries'.

Look at where we ended up. We have a manufacturing industry in this country employing less than 15 per cent of the work force. What an indictment that is on all politicians in this country over the last 30 years but, particularly, politicians in the Liberal-Country Party Government which dominated politics in this country for most of that period. What an indictment! Yet Senator Puplick had the nerve to come into this chamber, to dredge up some ideas about the problems that we are experiencing with the CSIRO and to look away from the major issues that we are talking about here. I cannot understand how a man who is theoretically so intelligent, a man for whom I used to have time, can suddenly become just another two-bob politician who is prepared to make a speech and then walk out of the chamber rather than listen to the other side, let alone to open his eyes and ears to the debate about this very important issue.

There are some other issues I wish to raise today because they have been missed in this debate. The first point that I make is that science is not just a matter of what the top, most brilliant people in this country do or what the people based in the CSIRO and some of the higher education institutions are doing. It is not just that. It is about the whole community being exposed to the ethos, the practice and the excitement that science has. Yet what do we have? If we look at our schools we see that a large percentage of women students still are not exposed to science. They deliberately refuse to take science as an option in their school courses. We see a significant number of intelligent young people who have the ability to study science taking courses which are an option. For example, they will do an arts course rather than undertake a mixed course of arts and science. We see so many young people deliberately turning away from science in this community.

To some extent that problem has been caused by the inability of some of the people at the top levels of scientific activity in this country to sell the notion that science can be exciting, important and a career opportunity that most people should look at. The science community has pushed its head into the sand for the last 30 years in this country. How many of us in this chamber have some reasonable scientific background, some contact with science or some feeling of excitement about science? I would say few, very few, indeed. That is very much a problem which lies at the feet of scientists themselves.

It is interesting that Senator Archer in another place in another time has made statements to the media that scientists are now taking their heads out of the sand, they are becoming real political operators, they can demonstrate, they can make public statements, they can attack governments for not getting enough funding as if that is the right thing for scientists to do. It may well be that it is a necessary part of putting science on the political agenda. But it is a very superficial approach. If we are talking about changing this country and making science more important in what we do, we are talking 10 to 15 years down the track. We are talking about scientists needing to change the whole ethos in this community about the way we approach science. Holding demonstrations in Canberra and shouting at the Prime Minister and Minister Jones will not necessarily change votes. It will not even change what we really need to change in science, which is our general approach.

Senator Puplick has done us all a disservice today by coming in here with this very superficial motion which is intended to gather a few votes from disaffected scientists who probably had their hands out for research money and did not get it. As Senator Button said, one of the ways that Senator Puplick would solve our scientific problem-or at least get it off the political agenda-would be simply to hand money for research to those people who are, at the moment, being vociferous about the position of science vis-a-vis politics.

There is room for debate about science. There is certainly room for debate about the CSIRO. For example, who has raised the issue in this chamber about where the money is allocated within the CSIRO for research and development? Let me quote Mr Paul Grant, currently a patent attorney who, over 15 years, built up the CSIRO's commercial branch before leaving in 1984. He described the CSIRO as `a huge monument to past problems'. I am not criticising the CSIRO. I am saying that one view is coming through loudly and clearly which we need to debate in this chamber. He said:
There has been a huge emphasis on mining and agriculture, but there are no longer problems in these areas.
He went on to say:
These industries should now be doing their own research, instead of having it subsidised.

That is the point I want to finish on. He has raised one issue: the role of private enterprise in this country in funding research and development. This Government already funds, as a percentage of gross domestic product, more scientific research and development than Japan, Italy and Canada. I particularly mention Japan-the country that is known for the amount of money that it has put into research and development. Our Government spends more than the Japanese Government, as a percentage of the gross domestic product, on research and development. That is because private enterprise in Japan pulls its weight in that area. Despite the 150 per cent tax grant which we give in Australia private enterprise has only managed to double its investment in research and development from a mere 0.24 per cent to about 0.48 per cent of gross domestic product. It is still a long way behind the eight ball.

The Minister, Senator Button, is moving in the direction of making private enterprise understand that it must, in Australia's interests and in its own long-term interests, put more into research and development. The scientific community ought to be backing that approach and this Parliament and this chamber should be backing the Minister too, instead of, as I said, supporting the Shake- spearian flourishes of the Opposition's spokesman, Senator Puplick, as evidenced by his appalling performance in this chamber today. I oppose the matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's debate on science, research and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) brings shame on the country, on the Parliament and on the Government in particular. My two colleagues, Senator Puplick and Senator Brownhill, have outlined many of the issues. I was disappointed that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in leading the debate for the Government, was not able to put forward anything to do with this subject. He was strong on bluster, as usual, and totally avoided the question, as usual.

SPEECH.PARA: Something which both Government speakers, the Minister and Senator Aulich, did not seem to take into account is that while other countries are spending more money overall, we believe that we can get by with spending less. Whatever those two speakers may have said, the fact is that everybody is spending more. Expenditure is increasing in all developed countries, but not here. It is all very well for Senator Aulich to say the best way we can get these people to work is to starve them-that is what it amounts to. Because it has been decided that a 30 per cent cut will do the CSIRO good, Senator Aulich comes up with the bright idea of making it 50 per cent. Thirty per cent did not work, so why would 50 per cent?

We should look at our position. The accepted definition of a Third World country is one that, firstly, has relied on agricultural exports for economic development and, secondly, has a lack of intellectual infrastructure. Does not that definition fit Australia the way it is today? Until recently Australia had the intellectual infrastructure to make it a developed nation but, with this Government's policies, we are being driven towards the famous banana republic prophecy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). This is something that the Government can ensure comes true.

How can the Government continue to wreck the future of science and Australia? Clearly, not one person or organisation has a good word for the Government or its science policy. It is interesting to note that the two Government speakers could not name one person or one organisation that has a good word for the Australian Labor Party since it came to government. The widely broadcast domestic brawls that go on on the subject within the Government are well known. It is no longer funny to see hopes built up by news items and then see them dashed. The status of Mr Barry Jones has been totally destroyed. In my term as shadow Minister, I greatly appreciated the many courtesies he showed me. But it is pathetic to see him now stripped of the duties for which he exhibited both a liking and a real enthusiasm, unlike anybody else in the Hawke Ministry.

Is it any wonder that the Sydney Morning Herald on 7 March 1989 reported that Jones was near to quitting the Cabinet? A couple of days later a newspaper report stated that, to try to patch things up, science might get a $350m injection. What did science get? It got nothing. Of course, that promise was rejected also. I would also like to refer to the despicable and disgraceful comments of Minister Dawkins, which were accepted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers, and the abusive way that he behaved when Mr Jones was at least trying to do something to get money for the science budget. Is it any wonder that things are in the disgraceful state they are?

Australia-wide scientific morale is appalling and most disturbing. There are so many statements to this effect that I do not know where to start. I was interested to see whether Senator Aulich was able to come up with one person or organisation that could have given the Government any support at all. Of course, he could not. My difficulty is knowing where to start and how many examples I can give in a short time. The point is that absolutely no-one supports the Government.

Senator Brownhill referred to the address given by Mr Allwright on 29 September last year to the National Farmers Federation. I will read a passage which the honourable senator did not quote. Mr Allwright said:

Scientific research has received shabby treatment from the Hawke government. Whether this is through ignorance or neglect is not clear. Frankly, it doesn't matter. The Government has no co-ordinated policy on the role of science and research apart from a few motherhood statements by the Labor Party Conference.
On page 3 of his address, Mr Allwright quoted what the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) had to say. That OECD report stated:

Australia needs to . . . promote understanding in the country and in the administration of the . . . relationship between technology, science and economic well-being. There seems to be less agreement about these relationships in Australia than in other industrialised countries.
That is the way we are heading at the moment.
The Australian Society for Medical Research, in a letter of 6 April, stated:

I am writing to draw your attention to a meeting of medical research scientists which occurred on 4 April at the University of Sydney. This followed meetings earlier this year of scientists, including medical researchers, at Lorne (Victoria), Melbourne and Canberra, all of which made representations to the Federal Government about the parlous state of science and medical research in Australia.
Does this mean we are gong to let medical research go down the gurgler too? Obviously it does. The letter further states:
In 1989, less than half of the `highly recommended' medical research projects could be funded by the NH & MRC because of lack of money.

It is not a lack of money; it is a lack of desire. The Treasurer is spouting about how much of a surplus he has. He has a surplus all right, because he is not spending money in essential areas. Further on, the letter says:
The whole tenor of the meeting was that we are facing over the next decade a virtual collapse of the scientific and medical sections of tertiary education.

The Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies represents 60,000 people employed in industry, government research establishments and throughout the education sector involving mathematics, science and technology. This is how it sees the situation. Its letter of 10 April addressed to me says:

It is with much regret that I write to you of what we see as the state of science and technology in Australia . . . Senator Button, the Minister responsible for the CSIRO, is blind to the problems that exist . . . Confidence in a career path in science and technology has been undermined by poor working conditions in the CSIRO, universities and colleges. Increasingly students are opting out of tertiary courses involving mathematics, science and technology.

That is the direction in which we are heading. Its letter to me included a copy of its submission on science, industry and technology. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate the submission in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The submission read as follows-
FEDERATION OF AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL SOCIETIES
GPO Box 2181, Canberra City 2601. Tel: (062) 47 3554; Fax: (062) 49 6419
Submission on Science, Industry and Technology

Through its seventy Member Societies FASTS represents 60,000 people employed in industry, government research establishments and administration and throughout the education sector in mathematics, science and technology. The membership of FASTS have indicated a number of concerns:

The shortage of trained personnel in key areas-For example, we are currently graduating fewer Ph.D's in the core sciences, physics, chemistry, mathematics, statistics and computing than we did five years ago even though there is high demand for them. We do not have sufficient experienced younger scientists and technologists in the system to replace the soon-to-retire large cohort recruited in the 1960's expansion of tertiary education and the CSIRO. The true picture is even more serious than the raw statistics indicate since in 1987 24 per cent of doctoral completions in science were from overseas;

Low job security and poor working conditions of young researchers-Opportunities in science and technology are not attractive enough to provide a basis for young researchers to build a secure career. A series of three-year contracts have become the norm for most young scientists. Students are now perceiving poor prospects for science graduates. There has been a 40% drift over the last decade of more talented students opting out of mathematics, science and technology at the end of secondary school. The latest evidence is of disastrously low cut-off scores for entry into some tertiary science courses;
The run-down of equipment in universities and colleges-A Department of Science survey showed a third of equipment to be useless or obsolete;

The switch of resources away from agricultural and geoscience research-The rapid expansion of the Asian economies will increase demand for commodities. We need to maintain our competitive edge through improved research. Primary products will continue to underpin the export sector for many years;

The low level of private sector research-The major problems are that many Australian companies are too small to have a viable research capacity; foreign-based transnational corporations have tended to carry out research at home; the stockmarket crash decreased the volume of venture capital and made it less adventurous so that new companies find it hard to get going; currency fluctuations deter planning of export expansion, what can sell at 65 cents US might not compete at 80 cents US; high interest rates make any kind of long-term investment unattractive, profits have to be distributed so that dividends can compete with bank rates. Companies will not carry out research when commercialisation of the results is problematic;

The lack of a co-ordinated Science and Technology policy to address these problems-Australia has no national policy on science and technology just a number of unco-ordinated initiatives in different portfolios.
The Reforms That Are Needed
For these reasons we favour immediate reforms along the following lines:-
The Prime Minister should head a committee of Ministers with portfolios that have a science and technology component. This committee should develop a national science and technology policy;
In terms of immediate additional Government funding the following is required:-
$20 million to replace university infrastructure funds transferred to the Australian Research Council and a cessation of further funds-transfer,
$150 million over the next three years to re-equip higher education institutions, CSIRO and other Government research agencies,
$60 million for the CSIRO to replace some of the programmes lost since 1983,
$25 million p.a. to lift post-graduate stipends to 75% of average weekly earnings,
$30 million over three years for an enhanced fellowship programme to keep experienced younger scientists, in science, in Australian.

The establishment of industry councils in manufacturing and service industries to sponsor R&D funded by a levy on industries which do not undertake adequate in-house levels of research. The management of these councils to be on a tripartite basis and involve active researchers;
The extension on the 150% R&D tax incentive by at least 2 years to 1993;
The maintenance and extension of the partnership scheme in DITAC and other Government programmes supporting industrial R&D.
An Industrial Research Strategy that takes Account of Australia's Economic problems

If interest rates remain high R&D should be encouraged in areas where research can be commercialised without large-scale investment-examples of this include computer software, scientific and medical instruments. Other research can be encouraged where the capital investment has largely been made, as in geoscience and agriculture, and in support industries such as chemicals.

R&D geared to product innovation and/or quality rather than cost-cutting can overcome problems of currency fluctuation particularly in exports to countries where innovation and quality matter more than price-Western Europe, North America and Japan. Product innovation depends very much on basic research and this should be strongly encouraged.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Canberra Times of 7 April, Professor Larkins, the President of the Federation, was reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: As long as the CSIRO reports only to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, there is a real danger that its research will be distorted to conform with the department, according to the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies.

Professor Larkins sees the problems as being that CSIRO reports to the wrong department. I think we all agree with him. But the Government sees it the other way. It is making science more introverted. Less real research is going on. Senator Puplick quoted Dr Coogan. Dr Coogan is certainly not a wild radical. He says much the same as many senior, dedicated people say. What does the Academy of Science say? Senator Puplick also mentioned Professor Stone, the Secretary of the Academy, who said:
By omission, the Government makes clear that it has no policy on science, except that it should provide short-term economic returns.

That is what the Government is looking for. That is the perception of industry and academia. It is quite true. On 22 October last year a letter appeared in the Canberra Times which started off by saying:
WE, COUNCIL members of the Australian Academy of Science, are deeply concerned over trends in the funding and administration of scientific research by the Federal Government.
The academy is appalled by the lack of effective consultation about many of the changes which have already taken place, as well as those currently under consideration.
The letter is signed by the entire executive membership of the Council. What about the Australian Institute of Engineers? On 12 April this year an article appeared in the Australian, which stated:
The reorganisation of the CSIRO implemented by its chairman, Mr Neville Wran, was out of control, the director of public affairs of the 45,000-member institute, Mr Michael Dack, said.

That is what the Australian Institute of Engineers says. It is not what I say. It is not what some newspaper says. It is what Mr Dack says. He speaks for the Institute of Engineers. My comments so far have covered the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Society of Medical Research, the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies, leading CSIRO scientists, the Academy of Science and the Australian Institute of Engineers. All these people are saying the same thing. The Board of the CSIRO asked for extra money. What did it get? It did not get anything, either. The situation is disastrous. No one with any clout in the Government is dealing with it. Where can we hope to go? It is a pity.

If the scientific community is not going to get support from outside, what about from inside? Mr Wran, the Chairman of CSIRO, does not say, `The CSIRO is made up of a great bunch of people, but there are various problems'. He was reported on 6 December as follows:

. . . there was no demoralisation at the CSIRO and that any dissent among its scientists came from people who `are not doing their jobs properly, because if they were, they'd be too bloody busy to be demoralised'.
Is that not lovely? This is the Chairman of CSIRO speaking about his senior scientists in this manner. He was reported as saying:
`We're going through a slightly difficult patch, but I don't regard it as a crisis in CSIRO. It's a period of change,' . . .

There is only one change that the CSIRO needs, and that is right at the top. Any scientist in Australia will say the same thing. If the CSIRO does not get support from its Chairman, what about the Minister? The following headline appeared in the Australian newspaper on 3 April, `Button attacks CSIRO on research'. That is a lot of help. It is a great morale booster for people who are working in second rate conditions. They are short of equipment, short of leadership, diminishing in numbers, lurching from one crisis to the next. On 9 April this year the Canberra Times reported the following:
. . . CSIRO would need to reduce spending by $14.2m in 1989-90, mainly due to shortfalls in land and asset sales.
`This will mean that some research will have to be stopped . . .
`The number of appropriation-funded staff will need to be reduced by 500 over the next three years to achieve a proper balance in the budget,'.

If one were a research scientist in the CSIRO, would that not give one great courage? Would one want to arrange for one's student children to go into science and research and look for a position in the CSIRO if that were the future? An article in the Age on 30 November talks about the Australian Research Council. It states:

Its placement in the Department of Education, Employment and Training represents a further fragmentation of science policy-making, which is already scattered between Senator John Button's Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Mr John Dawkins's Employment, Education and Training, Mr John Kerin's Primary Industry and Energy and Mr Hawke's own Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

That list does not even include Senator Richardson's Department. Where are we heading? What is happening to Australia's position in the world? We are behind only Brazil and Mexico when it comes to what we owe. We have not done enough homework to see that we are up to date with the latest technologies, trends and manufactures. Why would we want to keep going down this path when clearly there is something we can do? I do not think that Australia can or will return to a reasonable level of international scientific research with the current Government attitude. The Government should stand condemned for what it has done. I certainly support the matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Button said in this debate, obviously the Opposition had to bring before the Senate something like this matter of public importance today because of its great concern that next week's statement will chop out the ground from underneath it. It is quite clear that the matter of public importance was ill-considered and ill-prepared. We have had the photocopy-led science policy. A series of newspaper articles has been trotted out by three Opposition speakers, who somehow managed to take up 50 minutes of the Senate's time reading a series of excerpts from a lot of other people.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike most honourable senators who have spoken in this debate-but not Senator Archer, I acknowledge-being a senator for the Australian Capital Territory, I have had the opportunity to visit the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and talk to the scientists there not once but on several occasions. I have also visited the Australian National University. I had the opportunity to go to the CSIRO on its open day. I met the shadow Minister for science as he then was, Mr Warwick Smith. I found it interesting to see that he was held in high regard. Obviously, he had done a lot of work. People thought that perhaps somebody in the Opposition was starting to come to grips with science policy. On that day he returned to the Parliament from the open day of the CSIRO to find that he had been sacked. He must have been starting to find out something about science policy. As I have said, I also had the opportunity recently of going to the Australian National University and visiting several science research schools. I take this opportunity to thank the relevant scientists for their courtesy and assistance on that day.

I would like to draw on some of that experience and on some of the things that were said to me on those occasions, but before I do I want to make two preliminary comments. Members of the Opposition have a continuing problem in issues such as this on which Government members are called upon to speak. They refuse to recognise that, in the Federal Budget, the whole must equal the sum of the parts. They keep advocating that the Budget should be cut and that fiscal policy should be tighter, but on every issue that comes up they want more money to be spent. The problem is that we cannot have both. The whole must equal the sum of the parts. We do not need a science PhD to work out that if we spend more money in each area the total Budget will get bigger and fiscal policy will not be tighter. We cannot have both.

Before I go to the main thrust of the debate I want to make one other comment. I was surprised to hear Senator Archer's comments-he quoted people of authority, people for whom I have a lot of regard-about health and medical research funding. I happen to have before me-I am not surprised that they were not mentioned in the terms of the matter of public importance-figures for the last six years of funding of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). In those six years funding has increased by 110 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —So has the need.

—There is never too much. I am not pretending that it is a waste, but funding has gone up from $33m to $70m-in real terms, an increase of $13m or 40 per cent to $46m. There has not been a cut in funding to the NHMRC; there has been a substantial improvement. A lot of other good research is going on in the public sector, of which I know Senator Archer is aware from his experience. That research should not be ignored. It should be acknowledged that a lot of people are doing very good research work.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than dealing specifically with the CSIRO, although I will make reference to it as Senator Button and Senator Aulich did, I want to refer more to science policy generally, including the CSIRO. The matter of public importance proposed by Senator Puplick today fails to recognise, amongst other things, that the comparative shortfall in research and development in Australia even now is not a shortfall in government research expenditures but in private sector expenditure. As other honourable senators have said, Australian Government funding of research is higher than that of Japan, Canada, Belgium, Switzerland and Italy. The figures are quite clear and quite stark. Excluding defence expenditure, the Government spent 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) on civil research and development in 1985-86, which is more than the amount spent by Italy, Canada, Belgium, Switzerland, Sweden, the United Kingdom, Japan and the United States of America, apart from all the other countries that are recognised by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) as small research and development performers. The countries that I have mentioned are recognised as large research and development performers. The problem is that at that time the private sector was contributing only 0.36 per cent of GDP to research and development, which was less than the figures applying to many other countries which certainly would not be regarded as leading research and development countries and has put us in the bottom half dozen countries in the OECD. So it has been quite proper for the Government to give a lot of emphasis and priority to encouraging private sector research and development. There has not been as much success as the initiatives deserved, but there has been substantial success. While recognising that the principal shortfall is in the contribution of the private sector, it is nevertheless necessary for the Government to act. We cannot sit and wait for the private sector to do its job. We must encourage it and give it the incentive, but the Government needs to act.

Unlike some of the matters of public importance on which I have been called upon to speak during my relatively brief period in the Senate, this matter of public importance, however ill-considered Senator Puplick's arguments in support of it might have been, at least raises an important question. I suspect that it fails to recognise the distinction between talking about important things and doing something important, but at least it brings into the Parliament a discussion of an important issue. Perhaps it has not been done in the best way it might have been and perhaps it is not the most positive proposal we have had-I have heard nothing positive whatsoever-but at least it brings up this important point: scientific research and development are very important to the economic restructuring of Australia. We will not turn our economy away from its dependence upon what we can grow, what we can dig up and what we can chop down without substantial research and investment by the private sector, turning that research into commercially valuable products or services. It is essential that we recognise that reality in this difficult period of restructuring.

This debate needs some positive elements-not negative ones. It is not much use listing a litany of complaints-some of which might be valid and some of which might not-without an analysis. Let us get down to talking about some positive things: things that the Government has done and things that it appears will be under serious consideration next week and which I hope will be done. The Government has been doing the most important short term thing in the area of research and development, which is addressing the question of encouraging the private sector, not because it is the only area where we need research and development but because that is where the greatest shortfall has existed.

Total research and development in Australia has increased by 39 per cent in real terms since 1981-82. That figure sounds pretty grand. I do not want to overstate its significance because we started from an appallingly low base. It is always easy to get an increase when the base from which we start is sufficiently low. We were left with an appalling legacy, but there has been some achievement. As a share of GDP, Australia's research and development has gone from one per cent to 1.25 per cent, which is a substantial improvement, but we have a long way to go before we start to get into the big league of the large research and development performers which have figures of over 2 per cent and in some cases nearly 3 per cent. Even the medium range research and development performance within the OECD is 1.74 per cent. We have a long way to go even to get there. We have to increase our research and development three times as much as it has been increased since 1981 to get to that level, and that should be a minimum objective.

I think it is laudable that business expenditure in research and development has almost doubled since 1981-82 from a deplorable 0.24 per cent to 0.46 per cent in 1986-87. That trend continues to increase. Last financial year the private sector spent $1.2 billion on research and development. Those things are welcome. They are not enough but they are welcome. They are substantial. That is the first positive thing that needs to be recognised. The first positive thing that needs to be asserted is that more needs to be done. I certainly have the view that the options that are open to continue that incentive ought to be seriously considered and at least some of them adopted. For example, the continuation of the 150 per cent research and development deduction and the associated grants for industry research and development scheme can make a substantial contribution. There is also the teaching company scheme, which will add to the private sector's contribution to research and development and contribute to the very important aspect of the retention and development of our scientists. Sometimes in listening to the advocates of the scientific community one would think that the purpose of government science policy was to give jobs to scientists. That is certainly not the case, but we cannot achieve our science objectives without people feeling that there is a career option ahead of them: some encouragement to pursue science as a career and to remain in science as a career, and to stay in Australia to do so.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) spoke about the brain gain. As he has referred to it in other circumstances, I will not. Nonetheless, some real concerns need to be addressed concerning the Commonwealth postgraduate research awards, which are referred to in the Smith report. The Smith report also refers to the need for fellowships for outstanding young scientists. A problem is emerging in the area of higher education staffing, with a surge in staffing in a whole range of areas-for the moment, we are just talking about science-that occurred in the early to mid 1970s.
