PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate on behalf of Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to establish the Australian National Maritime Museum.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish the Australian National Maritime Museum as an independent statutory authority. The Government considers that the museum should have an independent role similar to other national collecting institutions, which will provide it with a permanent and distinctive presence in the community. The museum's statutory status will also strengthen its ability to seek sponsorship from the corporate sector.

Many honourable senators will have already noticed that the museum's prominent building, with its billowing sail roofline, is taking shape on its prime site at the entrance to Darling Harbour. In November 1985, the then Government agreed to provide $30m to enable the construction of the building for the Australian National Maritime Museum. The cost of establishing and installing the exhibitions, including the fit-out of the building, will be $9.5m. Most of this expenditure will be incurred in 1989-90. The site at Darling Harbour, which provides a superb maritime environment for the museum, was provided by the New South Wales Government. It was hoped that the museum would open during the Bicentenary. However, it is now anticipated that the museum will open its doors to the public during the second half of 1990.

The need for an Australian National Maritime Museum, reflecting the significance of maritime activity in the history and cultural life of Australians, was recognised over a decade ago in the 1975 Report of the Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections, better known as the Pigott report. This Government has reaffirmed the need for an institution to provide Australians with a central and comprehensive record of their past and present dependence on the sea. The Australian National Maritime Museum will provide a national focus for our maritime history and an insight for its domestic and international visitors into a major facet of our cultural heritage tradition, until now little acknowledged.

An earlier Bill to establish the museum was introduced in Parliament in 1986, but lapsed owing to the 1987 Federal elections. Subsequently, the Government reviewed its involvement in the development of Commonwealth museums and similar collecting and exhibiting institutions and this has further delayed consideration of this matter. The Government announced in the 1988-89 Budget context that the Australian National Maritime Museum should be primarily an exhibition oriented institution and provided capital and recurrent financial resources to reflect this decision.

The functions of the museum will be to exhibit, in cooperation with other public and private institutions, maritime historical material included in the national maritime collection or objects on loan to it. The museum will also be able to conduct, and assist with research and disseminate information relating to Australian maritime history and also the functions of the museum. Most importantly the museum will have a national role and will not compete with State or Territory institutions. Rather it will complement their collections and already strong co-operative links are being forged between the national, State and regional maritime museums.

The Bill empowers the museum to develop a collection of maritime historical material known as the National Maritime Collection. The Museum Council will determine the material to be included in this collection, based upon criteria and guidelines approved by the Minister. The museum will also be able to purchase historical and other relevant material, accept gifts and bequests and acquire and operate vessels of historical interest and significance.

Maritime historical material is defined in the Bill to mean material relating to Australian maritime history and archaeology which includes the natural history of Australia, the history of the interaction of human beings with the Australian marine environment and the history of sea travel for every purpose. The reference to Australian marine environment includes the sea above the continental shelf and the subsoil of the continental shelf adjacent to the Australian coast. It also includes the environment of the lakes, rivers and internal waters of Australia. This allows the museum effectively to acquire any material of a maritime nature provided it has a connection with Australia.

The Bill will apply not only to the Australian mainland but to its external territories, past and present. However, material of significance from Australian external territories in the Pacific, Indian and Southern oceans and Antarctica will be transferred to the National Maritime Collection only after consultation by my Department and the museum with the local governing body of the relevant territory.

Much of Australia's historical material reflecting the involvement of its people with the sea has never been exhibited on a large scale. The Government intends that the displays will be exciting and stimulating-they will not be a mere collection of inanimate objects. On opening it is expected that there will be six major exhibition themes, namely: Finding Australia; Travellers-the Long Sea Voyage; Commerce-the Working Sea; Navy-from Bluejackets to Battleships; Leisure-Sun, Surf, Sail; and Australia-USA-Linked by the Sea. The Australia-United States of America gallery will be a permanent gallery funded as a Bicentennial gift from the United States, to commemorate over two centuries of maritime contact between the two countries. Another gallery will be used for temporary and travelling exhibitions.

The museum's fleet, which will be a major attraction, will be moored at the two finger-wharves alongside the museum and will complement the indoor exhibitions. Some of the most notable vessels in the fleet include the Akarana, an 1888 gaff-rigged racing cutter which was a Bicentennial gift from New Zealand; the Kathleen Gillett, a veteran of the first Sydney-Hobart yacht race and Norway's Bicentennial gift; the John Louis, a sturdy pearling lugger from Western Australia and three vessels representing the Navy. Some of these ships are on loan from our other national collecting institutions. One very important vessel that will not be at the wharves is Australia's best-known yacht Australia II. However, it will dominate the museum's tall gallery.

In keeping with its primary role as an exhibition oriented institution, the museum will be a place of education, participation and enjoyment-in short, a dynamic institution. Indeed, one of the refreshing features of the museum will be its acknowledgment of children as an important part of the visiting public. A special discovery room will provide a unique attraction for the youngest visitors. In addition, there will be an education centre located within the museum complex for use by groups which visit the museum as part of the formal education programs offered by the museum.

The museum will have an exciting calendar of indoor and outdoor entertainments throughout the year. One of the museum's biggest attractions will be the floating exhibits about which I spoke earlier. Visitors may expect to board some of the vessels to find costumed role players, cooking demonstrations in the galleys or demonstrations of mast climbing or sail furling.

I turn now to the museum's management. A Museum Council is to be established by this Bill which will ensure the proper and efficient management of the museum and determine its policy, subject to ministerial direction. The Council will give directions to the director of the museum with regard to the management of the affairs of the museum. The Council will consist of a chairperson, a director and no fewer than seven nor more than 10 members appointed by the Governor-General. An appointed member will possess knowledge and experience relating to Australian maritime history or other areas of knowledge relevant to the affairs of the museum. The chairperson and other members are appointed on a part-time basis.

The day-to-day management of the museum will be conducted by a director who shall be appointed for a period of up to seven years. The director shall have all the powers of a secretary to a department in relation to the staff of the museum who will be employed under the Public Service Act 1922.

While the museum will be funded through the annual budgetary process, the Bill also provides for the establishment of a national maritime museum fund. Money paid into the fund will include gifts and bequests or money received from the disposal of property given to the museum, other than on trust. Money from the fund will be spent in accordance with the functions of the museum.

The museum is being encouraged by the Government to adopt an entrepreneurial outlook in organising its activities. The Bill empowers the museum to develop sponsorship proposals and to carry out a broad range of commercial activities. Indeed, the museum has embarked already on an active program of seeking corporate support and raising the museum's public profile. Situated as it is on a prime site in Darling Harbour, the museum will not only benefit from this particular urban renewal development but will also attract substantial numbers of tourists in its own right.

It is estimated that based on 1988-89 prices the annual ongoing running costs of the museum will be in the order of $6.823m and that the cost of preserving, documenting and building the collection will be of the order of $854,000 per annum. The increased costs associated with the museum becoming a statutory authority are expected to be offset by its ability to generate revenue through sponsorship and commercial activities, such as charging an admission fee. In addition, part of its building will be leased for use as a restaurant to serve its patrons and as a shop for those visitors who wish to purchase posters, books and a range of quality goods and souvenirs to remind them of their visit.

The museum is required by this Bill to prepare annual estimates of expenditure. The Council shall be responsible for the preparation of strategic plans, on a three year cycle, as well as annual operational plans. The museum shall be subject to audit by the Auditor-General and will be obliged to prepare an annual report by virtue of being subject to certain provisions of the Audit Act 1901.

The establishment of the Australian National Maritime Museum by this Bill is an example of the Government's commitment to the preservation and display of Australia's heritage. The museum will become one of our most important national cultural institutions as well as a centre of excellence in communicating our national maritime heritage. The museum will be recognised as a place where the richness and diversity of our past and present achievements as a maritime nation are documented and can be experienced. It will not restrict its displays to the past history of Australia as a maritime nation; it will also focus on our contemporary achievements. The spacious forecourt, which opens onto a dramatic view of the city skyline, has been named the Ben Lexcen Walk in honour of the man who made maritime history by designing the Australian winner of the America's Cup. Significant maritime achievements of all Australians will be well documented in the collection.

I believe that this new national museum will become a proud achievement with a strong commitment to educating and entertaining all of its visitors. I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill is an omnibus Bill for legislation administered within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio. Its introduction will facilitate the passage of amendments to existing legislation.

The Bill contains minor administrative amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Collection Act 1964 and repeals the redundant Derby Jetty Agreement Act 1962, Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Act 1986, Pipeline Construction (Dalton to Canberra) Act 1980, Pipeline Construction (Young to Wagga Wagga) Act 1980, South Australia Grant (Fruit Canneries) Act 1971, States Grants (Fruit-growing Reconstruction) Acts of 1972, 1973, 1974 and 1976, Victoria Grant (Shepparton Preserving Company Limited) Act 1971 and Wheat Industry Stabilization Fund (Disposal) Act 1962. These amendments will be self evident and are sufficiently explained in the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more significant changes which will be made by the Bill.
Plant Variety Rights Act 1987

Sections 12 and 38 of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 will be amended to give the grantee of Plant Variety Rights the right to produce (or licence others to produce) plants or reproductive material of the protected variety for the commercial production of fruit, flowers or other products of the variety.

The present Act does not recognise the practical difference between propagation from seed and the much more rapid process of asexual reproduction. It allows a person to buy a small number of protected plants from the breeder and in a short time asexually propagate a commercial planting. If only the product such as fruit and cut flowers are sold, and not the plants or reproductive material, the Act is not infringed and the grower rather than the breeder of the new variety receives the commercial gain.
The objective of the Act is to stimulate plant breeding by giving sole rights to the breeder for a period of 20 years. This was not happening under the present provisions.
Overseas countries and the International Union for the Protection of New Plant Varieties (UPOV) Convention have provisions similar to those proposed in this amendment.

Sections 18 and 28 are being amended to ensure that public notice of decisions is given as soon as possible but provides the flexibility needed for the quarterly publication of the Plant Varieties Journal.
Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation

The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Exploration Permit Fees) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Pipeline Licence Fees) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Production Licence Fees) Act 1967, Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Registration Fees) Act 1967, and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Retention Lease Fees) Act 1985 contain provisions for the charging of fees for applications and annual rentals for titles granted by the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 and for registration of dealings affecting, and transfers of, titles.

Amendments in this Bill will enable the determination of the level of application and rental fees, minimum registration fees and securities required under the legislation, by regulation rather than by amending the principal Act. This will enable the timely adjustment of these fees and securities so that they more closely reflect actual administrative costs. All fees collected in respect of the State and Northern Territory adjacent areas are paid to the States/Northern Territory in recognition of the costs incurred in administering day-to-day petroleum activities in these areas.

An amendment will also abolish the provision for refunds of application fees to unsuccessful applicants for titles under the legislation. Experience with administering the legislation has shown that costs of assessing applications are the major costs involved in the application process and the abolition of refunds will enable application fees to reflect actual administrative costs incurred.
Another amendment will enable a fee to be charged for an application for a special prospecting authority. Again this change will more closely align fees with administrative costs.

Under the existing legislation, renewals of titles can only be granted to the applicant for the renewal. In such cases it has been necessary to postpone approval and registration of a transfer until after the renewal has been granted. An amendment will enable the timely approval and registration of transfers which otherwise would be held up until a renewal of a title is granted.

Seismic surveys and other types of surveys undertaken by holders of special prospecting authorities over vacant acreage are an important factor in stimulating interest in offshore petroleum exploration and competition in bidding for exploration acreage. An amendment will facilitate such activities by enabling holders of special prospecting authorities to apply for an access authority to adjoining title areas in order to link new surveys with existing surveys or wells. In such cases the Designated Authority will be expected to take account of the views of affected titleholders before granting an access authority. Holders of special prospecting authorities will be expected to comply with any special conditions applying to the area covered by the access authority and not interfere with the activities of titleholders. At present, holders of special prospecting authorities must rely on an existing titleholder to apply on their behalf for approval to undertake the survey in the title area.

Another amendment will facilitate the provision of access authorities to enable access to adjoining acreage which is administered by a different State or Territory. The amendment will enable a titleholder, or holder of a special prospecting authority, to apply to the relevant Designated Authority for an access authority in an adjoining adjacent area thus ensuring that a titleholder only has to seek approval from one Designated Authority.

However, the amendment will ensure that the consent of the Designated Authority for the adjoining adjacent area is gained prior to the granting of the access authority. The holders of such authorities will be expected to comply with any special conditions applying to the area covered by the access authority.

The repeal of section 57 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act will remove the requirement to undertake a minimum amount of work or produce an equivalent value of petroleum, in production licence areas. This will enable production licence holders to determine their own investment priorities. However, the Government still has powers under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act to require a discovery to be developed at specific production rates.

The amendments will have no net impact on the Commonwealth budgetary position as any increased revenue from fees will be offset by payments of those increased fees to the State/Northern Territory. Those payments will assist the States and the Northern Territory in recovering costs they incur on behalf of the Commonwealth in the administration of offshore petroleum activities in adjacent areas.

The proposed amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) legislation have been the subject of consultation with the States, the Northern Territory and the industry and have general support. They are essential to the effective and efficient administration of the Commonwealth's offshore petroleum legislation.
Tobacco Marketing Act 1965

The proposal to change the name of the Australian Tobacco Board to the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee follows a review of the Board carried out in conjunction with Government consideration of the assistance arrangements to apply to the tobacco growing and manufacturing industries.

Legislation to give effect to the assistance arrangements announced by the Government on 19 November 1988 will be introduced separately. This Bill is proposed to give effect to the name change foreshadowed in that announcement.

The Australian Tobacco Board, established by the Tobacco Marketing Act 1965, comprises representatives of tobacco growers, manufacturers, the Commonwealth and the three States in which tobacco is grown. The Board's principal task is to administer the tobacco industry stabilisation plan which is primarily directed at increasing the competitiveness of the tobacco leaf growing industry. The plan, which was recently extended to 1993, is the final in a series of five year plans which commenced in 1965.

In pursuing stabilisation plan objectives, the Board makes recommendations to Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for agriculture on annual determinations of tobacco leaf prices and quotas. The Board acts largely as a negotiating forum and has no role in the receival, handling or sale of tobacco leaf. The latter functions are carried out by statutory leaf marketing boards in the tobacco growing States.

The name change proposed reflects the Board's major function of advising Ministers on prices and quotas. It also recognises that its functions differ from those of the main body of statutory marketing authorities within the primary industry portfolio to which recent major policy and legislative reforms were directed. The Bill is confined therefore to giving effect to the name change and a minor operational amendment made necessary by the abolition of the Public Service Board.
As the Australian Tobacco Board is named in complementary State legislation, the name change will not take effect for six months so that States may legislate for a common date of effect.
None of the proposed amendments have any significant financial impact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 and the Circuit Layouts Bill 1988 was adjourned on 12 April 1989 I had made a number of comments about the copyright legislation. I do not want to go over all the ground that I covered on that occasion. I will briefly indicate the matters I raised at the time. Firstly, I was concerned about the exceptional complexity of this legislation. Secondly, I was concerned about the lack of precision in advice from the Attorney-General's Department on a range of issues. Thirdly, I indicated that a number of initiatives in the Bill were supported by the Opposition because they reflected views which the Opposition had expressed in its published arts policy, namely, support for the levy on blank tapes, support for adherence to certain sections of the Rome Convention securing protection for performers and support for changes to the copyright law to allow works of dance choreography to be accorded copyright protection if they are recorded on video.

SPEECH.PARA: I had made some comments about the blank tape levy. I now wish to return to that matter. This Bill proposes the introduction of a levy on blank audio tapes which will be the subject of some further remarks by my colleague Senator Michael Baume. The purpose of this measure is not only to reward performers in an indirect fashion for the loss which they might suffer as a result of home taping but also to provide a source of revenue to help the Government finance a non-profit organisation to support Australian contemporary music development. The 15 per cent or so levy is to go towards funding the Australian Contemporary Music Development Company (ACMDC) to contribute to the promotion of Australian contemporary music.

Contemporary music is an important industry in Australia. Australian bands of note, such as INXS, the Little River Band, AC DC, Air Supply and Men At Work are a significant economic factor in the arts scene and the music industry in Australia. For example, INXS, which is one of the primary bands operating in Australia, has estimated record sales grossing more than $150m. One could add to the list of bands I have already mentioned Crowded House, Midnight Oil and a number of other bands which make a significant contribution to the economic and cultural life of this country.

Recently I corresponded with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins), in whose portfolio area a great deal of the support operations for Australian contemporary music falls, to try to get some definition of what exactly constitutes contemporary music-whether contemporary music is to be taken as synonymous with rock music. Contemporary music is, after all, written for theatre, for dance and for operatic performances. Contemporary music should not necessarily be regarded as being synonymous with rock music. On 21 March this year, in reply to some of my correspondence, the Minister said:

In planning for the establishment of the ACMDC the Government has placed a broad interpretation on the word `contemporary'. It is recognised that in many aspects of the music industry, for example, training, promotion and production, there are elements which are common to the various styles of music.

I believe that is a proper attitude for the Government to have taken to the definition of contemporary music. Because of time constraints, although there is much that could be said about contemporary music in Australia, I will raise a number of other issues, some of which I hope the Minister will have an opportunity to reply to when he concludes the second reading debate. However, before I raise those matters I want to refer to the question of the protection of performers and the operation of the Rome Convention as it applies through this copyright legislation. In April 1985 the Copyright Law Review Committee issued its discussion paper on performers' protection. It set out there the terms and arrangements of the Rome Convention and it presented some quite significant arguments in favour of legislation to give effect to that Convention. I think they are well enough known for me not to have to rehearse them. I simply say that one of the difficulties which have arisen with this piece of legislation is the proposal to give it some retrospective operation in terms of the protection of performers' rights.

Representations were made to the Government on that matter and I understand that the Government is to introduce an amendment to the legislation which will make the operation of performer's protection legislation prospective rather than retrospective. In that endeavour it will have the support of the Opposition. That is an amendment which we would have moved if the Government had not moved in that direction.

However, there are still a number of matters which arise in relation to things such as the definition of the term `performance'. Mr Deputy President, I shall indicate to you, to the Minister and to the officers present that, apart from the amendments which we have already described in broad outline in terms of Senator Hill's previous speech on this matter, we will also be seeking one further amendment dealing with the definition of `performance'-that is, to ensure that the legislation provides that it shall not be taken to be a performance where the undertaking recorded is a participation in a performance by a person or persons acting as a member or members of an audience. We believe that some representations have adequately been made out on that matter.

However, the issue that I want to spend a few moments on in relation to general copyright issues is the copyright protection of Aboriginal works of art. Again, this is an extraordinarily complicated issue to come to grips with, as are all copyright matters. I appreciate that difficulties are found all round in the adjustment of issues of copyright. None of them presents more difficulty at the moment than looking at the protection of Aboriginal works of art. Mr Deputy President, as you would know with your interest in art and in art matters, one of the matters which have come to attention in recent years has been the unauthorised copying of original Aboriginal works of art-whether they are reproduced in designs on tee-shirts, tea-towels or souvenirs essentially related to the tourist trade without any proper appreciation of the concept of copyright protection and ownership accruing to the Aboriginal artist or group of artists.

For example, if we look at an article which appeared in the March 1989 newsletter of the National Association for the Visual Arts entitled `Issues in Copyright: ``Aboriginal wear'' ', we see that that article has raised a number of significant issues. The issue which perhaps is most central to trying to sort out some way through this labyrinth is the question of group ownership of art and, consequently, group ownership of a copyright. The article very rightly points out that European law, upon which our own copyright protection is founded, does not recognise group ownership of art. Copyright legislation in European law has a long history. In terms of actual statute law I think it is legislation which goes back to the reign of Queen Anne.

At no stage has copyright ever been thought to have been vested in anything other than individuals. Clearly, that is not appropriate within the Australian context. Clearly, in terms of Aboriginal art, ownership of original works of art is very often believed to be vested not in the individual artist, the individual painter, or the individual craftsman but in a group-either a tribal group, a linguistic group or a kinship group. Customary law in Aboriginal communities recognises that sort of nature of ownership which is totally incompatible with the basis upon which copyright law has been drawn in this legislation and throughout history as far as European legislation is concerned.

Again, we have no specific amendments to offer at this stage on this matter. But we seek from the Government some comment from the responsible Minister as to whether the Government is interested in actively pursuing a greater degree of protection to be accorded to Aboriginal works of art and whether it believes it is possible to vest copyright ownership not in an individual but in some group or in some association of individuals. The coalition parties have stated in our own Aboriginal affairs policy that we are committed:

. . . to the conservation and preservation of Aboriginal heritage, including sacred sites, artefacts, traditions and art. We believe that they should be preserved as an integral element of our national cultural life.
We go on in our policy with respect to Aboriginal art to say:
We will encourage Aboriginal artists to develop their skills and to help train other members of their communities.
We are committed to achieving a higher profile of traditional Aboriginal art and culture in the mainstream of Australian society.

I believe that one of the ways in which that can be positively encouraged is to look at the copyright arrangements as they relate to questions of Aboriginal art and to the protection of Aboriginal art and Aboriginal design in the way in which I have just indicated.

Again, because of time constraints, I do not want to continue that line of argument at any greater length. However, I want to come back to a number of previous comments which I have raised in relation to this legislation. I believe that Senator Hill, in his excellent speech setting out our view on this matter when the question was being debated last month, has made it clear that there are a number of aspects of this legislation which we regard as unsatisfactory. We have a long schedule of amendments which we propose to move and, undoubtedly, the committee stage of this debate will be extremely technical. Mr Deputy President, because of your interest and expertise in copyright matters you have participated in many discussions in the Opposition parties. As I have said, I do not propose to go over all of Senator Hill's amendments this evening.

However, I want to conclude by making a number of remarks which come back to my areas of responsibility in my capacity as the shadow Minister for the arts. I believe that the amendments, which seek to entrench in the legislation the blank tape royalty, are entirely proper and they certainly have the support of the Opposition. I believe that the protection extended to performers by adhering to certain parts of the Rome Convention are entirely proper. They are supported by the Opposition and we commend the Government for having picked up our suggestions that those should not be given any retrospective operation but should be made entirely prospective as far as that protection is concerned.

We indicate that amendments which will be made to the schedule in the principal Act in order to allow works of choreography primarily to be recorded on video and accorded copyright in that status rather than relying upon the traditional choreological techniques which have been used to record dance notation which, of course, is an extremely specialised form of activity-there is a great shortage of choreologists in this country; people who are trained and competent at writing down dance notation in a form which would normally attract copyright protection-are also an excellent initiative and the Government and its advisers are to be commended in that respect. I have indicated the additional amendment which my colleague Senator Hill will be offering to cover the position where a person appears in a recorded fashion as a member of an audience rather than as a primary performer to ensure that that person is not caught up in the provisions which define what constitutes a recording under this piece of legislation. I indicate the support which the Opposition has been happy to extend to the Government over a prolonged period for its initiatives in relation to the development of contemporary music in Australia. The Opposition, of course, is anxious to see this piece of legislation passed. We are anxious to press our amendments and I expect a quite vigorous and interesting committee debate to take place on this piece of legislation.

I wish simply to indicate the support we have for the general thrust of this legislation. I make one final appeal, however, to the Government, which I think it will eventually have to take on board-or we will when we are in government-namely, that this legislation is clearly in need of very substantial revision, clarification and elucidation. When a piece of legislation has a section, if my memory serves me correctly, 135zzzb, it is absolutely ridiculous to expect that anybody could follow it coherently.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like the taxation Act.

—As Senator Walsh quite rightly says, it is just about as nightmarish as the Income Tax Assessment Act and almost as nightmarish as the Broadcasting Act. At some stage, some rationality will have to be brought into copyright legislation. I do not know that this Government has the will to do that. It will certainly be one of the matters which the next Government will address very seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Puplick in supporting the thrust of the Government's proposed amendments to the Copyright Act, a monumental Act which certainly needs fixing up, as Senator Puplick has said. The amendments are designed to put a royalty on blank recording tape used for home audio taping; to protect performers from unauthorised recording or broadcasting of their live performances; to enable educational institutions to videotape television programs; to streamline the existing licences to educational institutions to photocopy; to enable institutions assisting the handicapped to make talking books and other useful materials; to clarify protection for industrial articles; and to streamline the statutory licence for record manufacture. As Senator Puplick has said, the Opposition supports the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 and the Circuit Layouts Bill 1988, but will move several amendments apart from the general second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad-and Senator Puplick has expressed similar pleasure-that the Government has amended elements of the copyright legislation as it affects performers' protection. What interested me was that the Government asserted, or at least the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) asserted in his second reading speech, that he and the Government had consulted a whole range of people involved with this matter. It is clear that not enough consultation went on. The Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS), the Advertising Federation of Australia (AFA) and the Australian Record Industry Association (ARIA), all made representations to the Government and to the Opposition concerning those parts of the Bill dealing with performers' protection. It was only as a result of those submissions, as I understand it, and of the threat of the Opposition moving appropriate amendments, that the Government belatedly agreed-I say belatedly because it is now May and this matter was debated in the lower House in November last-to ensure that there was no retrospective element in the performers' protection area. This is of some significance.

It is disappointing, as was pointed out by the Opposition in the other place at the time, that this matter of great importance was gagged through the House of Representatives, not allowing enough time not only to consider these matters but also to place an effective argument in front of the people. It has been left to the Senate to have, for the first time, a detailed and proper examination of matters which were prevented from being properly discussed by the imposition of a gag last November. The legislation is only now before the Senate and the Government is now presenting its own amendments to it. The word `sloppy' is probably appropriate in this matter as far as the Government is concerned. While, as I said, we totally support the thrust of the legislation, this is once again another example of how it could have been done better.

The problem which the Government has belatedly agreed to fix is so self-evident that it is extraordinary that it failed to do so. The retrospective nature of this Bill meant that it would apply 20 years back from when the Bill became law. Over that 20-year period, up to the date the Bill became law, producers, television stations and others might quite lawfully have made recordings, with or without the authority of the performers, specifically for replay. The usual practice, I understand, has been to pay performers a fee, including payment for future use and re-recording of their performances, without having specific approval for specific replay and specific re-recording. If that were so, and I understand it was, clearly it would have been a massive burden on those television stations, radio stations and so on, or on anyone else who wanted to replay something, to have to get the approval of every participant in that production. In the case of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, for example, this law would have required the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), when replaying a concert, to have the subsequent approval of every individual player in that orchestra, in that concert.

It astounds me that such a nonsense was allowed by this Government. Not only was it gagged through the House of Representatives, but its clear impossibility was not recognised until six months afterwards. FACTS, AFA, and ARIA say that, if the Government had not responded, if that provision had become law, they simply would not have been prepared to broadcast any performance recorded in the last 20 years, which is the protection period, because they would not have been able to obtain the authority of some performers and may have had to pay excessive amounts to obtain the authority of others.

The Bill, as it was drafted, and as it was rammed through the House of Representatives, would have caused practical problems for television stations and other recorders of performances. They would have been severe problems. Apart from anything else, the stations would have been liable for damages if they had re-recorded or rebroadcast a performance and if they had not obtained the authority of the performers. This authority had to be obtained from every performer. In the case of an orchestral concert recorded 15 years ago, it would be clearly ludicrous for one to try to find the approval of the second bassoon, who may well have transferred to the Stockholm Symphony Orchestra. The Government, having gagged the legislation through the lower House, is now prepared to accept that the Opposition and the other organisations with which it was supposed to have consulted were right all the time. I welcome that amendment.

I shall now deal with the question of the blank tape royalty scheme for home taping. As Senator Puplick said, this in its general thrust is a proposal that exists in the coalition's arts policy. Naturally, we find no difficulty with the principle. In fact, in 1982, when I was Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, I was preparing a Cabinet submission on exactly this matter. The Fraser Government then wanted to examine how this matter should be properly handled. I am sorry that our defeat in early 1983 meant that it has taken this Government seven years to bring this matter forward from the point that it had reached in late 1982. In a sense it is still half-baked. There are many matters in this proposal which, frankly, need a lot more examination and consideration than appear to have been given by the Government, despite the fact that it says that it has had detailed consideration with relevant industry participants.

As everybody knows, home taping is widespread in the community. Under the present law it is a breach of copyright to tape anything at home-that is, anything to which copyright applies, which is a great bulk of material broadcast by the radio stations and other bodies from which the copy is taken. Clearly, this law is honoured more in the breach than in the observance. I know of no prosecutions in recent times-possibly there may have been-for home taping. Indeed, recently industries have been developing which depend on the capacity and willingness of people to break the law. The law has not been effective. As we tried in 1982, so the present Government has been trying to find a solution, recognising that home taping does go on and yet ensuring that the copyright owners are compensated for the use of their material.

It is worth stressing that when one talks about copyright owners, it does not arise from some hate of those who do not deserve to get some recompense. It refers to people who by their talent have made something that is sufficiently worthwhile for someone else to have possession of. Surely if one's income depends on one's ability to create music either by writing or playing it, or by any of the other things that are copied, if one's livelihood depends on that, one has every right to require someone who seeks to acquire the proceeds of one's work to have to pay for it. I do not think anyone in this chamber would resile from that. It is proper and right that people who seek to have a song written by somebody in their possession should have to pay for that right. Home taping means that people have avoided that obligation to pay for what they have. In many instances this relates to Australian artists, the bulk of whom one could never accuse of being in the lap of luxury. There is no doubt that there is a need for equity and justice to be introduced in this area where in the past people have not been getting a fair go. Probably the bulk of Australians have been bludging on artists, musicians and so on by copying their works without having to pay them any fee for so doing.

Under the Government scheme, the thrust of which the Opposition supports, consumers will be able to home tape published recordings directly or off-air for their private and domestic use without any infringement of copyright. I stress that that is for their private and domestic use-not for pirating purposes and then selling to someone else. In return for that right to avoid infringing copyright by home taping, owners of copyright in recordings will receive some payment through a royalty which will be levied on blank recording tape. This was roughly the scheme which we were examining in 1982 and which is in the coalition's arts policy.

The Minister in the second reading speech said that this royalty will apply to audio tapes with playing times in excess of 30 minutes and will be calculated by reference to the length of the playing time. The actual amount of the royalty, the Minister said, will be determined by the Copyright Tribunal having regard to relevant matters such as, for example, the extent of home taping of eligible copyright material and the value to copyright owners of the material so taped.

Frankly, that leaves many questions unanswered. How much is the royalty to be? I understand that it is to be set by a tribunal, but are we looking at enormous amounts? I have seen suggestions from people that the figure could be 20c to 50c. I have seen other suggestions from performing rights organisations which say they want the figure to be a dollar. This could be a substantial amount of money or a little. I was interested to see at the end of the second reading speech that the Minister said:

The Copyright Amendment Bill will have a minimal impact on Commonwealth revenue and expenditure. There may be some increase in revenue due to a slight expansion of the sales tax base resulting from introduction of the blank tape royalty.

I am accustomed to the Government not knowing the consequences of its legislation, but I would have thought it reasonable to have some kind of ball park figure about what sort of money is likely to be raised when we are introducing this kind of legislation. It is one of the matters that I would much rather see dealt with much more thoroughly than the Government has done.

This matter has been opposed by the audio and video manufacturers and importers, and naturally so because they are the people who will have to pay the royalty. As the Minister pointed out, in the interests of minimising administrative costs of royalty collection, the duty to pay the royalty will be imposed on the first seller, that is the importers and manufacturers of blank tapes in Australia. Copyright owners, the Minister pointed out, will only be able to receive royalties where they are members of a single authorised collecting society, the rules of which have been approved by the Attorney-General. The collecting society will operate along similar lines to existing copyright collecting societies and will be responsible for the collection and distribution of the royalties. The Government therefore will not be involved in the running of the scheme and will not ultimately receive any part of the royalties.

The Government has pointed out that copyright owners who will benefit from the scheme will include composers, lyricists, authors, music publishing companies and record producers. The recording companies have agreed that a substantial share of the royalty will be passed on to performers under their contracts, which ordinarily would amount to about a third of the royalties collected by the society. The Minister has rightly said that the Government would be concerned if this share were eroded, and the Government will be monitoring this aspect closely.

There are many others matters relating to this legislation that I should like to deal with, and perhaps I should quickly address the fact that Australia would be ahead of many comparable countries in proceeding down this track, even though quite a number of European countries have already introduced, or are proposing to introduce, a blank tape royalty scheme, but others such as the United States do not have such a scheme. This creates problems when we are collecting royalties that relate to overseas artists' work. I think we have to resolve this a little better than we have, and I will have something to say about that when I deal with the Opposition's amendment. There is also a question of whether or not, instead of introducing this kind of royalty, one might not be better off banning equipment that does not incorporate some sort of anti-copy or spoiler device to prevent people engaging in home recording. This could be done rather than imposing some kind of tax on blank tapes. But the Government does not favour that and, I must say, neither does the Opposition.

Of course, the clear problem also emerges that many blank tapes are not used for copying copyright material. The Government's proposal, with which we have no objection, includes specific provisions to enable users such as schools, institutions for the blind and so on to purchase tapes that are free from any royalty while those people who buy tapes on which the royalty has been paid-in other words, people who are not capable of getting the exemption-but do not intend to use them for copying copyright material will, under the Government scheme, be able to obtain a refund of the royalty by filling out a statutory declaration. We think that is a fairly messy way of going about things and believe that that matter should be much more closely examined.

As the Minister has said, the Government has also been concerned to prevent the outflow of funds from Australia to foreign countries which do not reciprocate with similar benefits to Australian copyright owners. In years past this chamber may have thought that it was a waste of time worrying about any prospect of our outflow being offset by inflows from Australian works being played overseas. But it is very heartening these days, largely through the modern pop music industry, that Australia has the capacity to earn very large sums from overseas if such a scheme existed in those countries which at present do not have this arrangement. In any event, because the Government does not want this money to flow to countries that do not reciprocate with similar benefits for Australian copyright owners, the royalty will be collected for the benefit of only relevant copyright owners; that is, owners of Australian audio copyright materials and owners of audio copyright materials in those countries which have similar schemes and therefore provide comparable benefits to Australian owners. This will ensure that Australia adheres to the spirit of the relevant international copyright conventions without providing a windfall to foreign owners in countries which have not addressed the problem of home taping.

The Government also noted in its legislation that 15 per cent of the royalty raised will be set aside by copyright owners for the benefit of those people in the Australian music industry most in need of assistance. The music industry has agreed to provide part of the royalty to the Australian Contemporary Music Development Co., recently established by the Government to foster Australian contemporary music.
The problems that we have with the legislation are evident from the second reading amendment that has been moved on behalf of the Opposition. The amendment states:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) upon the commencement of Part Vc of the bill, or as soon as thereafter as may be practicable, the Government should refer the following matters to the Copyright Tribunal for inquiry and report:
(i) the extent to which audio tapes purchased in Australia are purchased with the intention of using them to record copyright material and non-copyright material respectively;

It seems to me extraordinary that we have no idea, judging from the Minister's second reading speech and the lack of any information to the contrary from the Government, of what proportion of tapes are used in taping copyright material.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you find out?

—I guess that there should be some kind of survey. It seems to me extraordinary that we are taking action because we think that there is an amount of tape usage out there without, in fact, having any idea whatsoever what that use is. I find it ludicrous and impossible to believe that no-one has any idea of the extent to which blank tapes are used for the copying of copyright material. I think we ought to know the consequences of what we are doing and whether the volume of exemptions sought by statutory declaration is going to be so enormous that we will be submerged in a sea of paper, rather than have a practical system for the collecting of moneys which should be due to those people who have copyright.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment also states that we want the Copyright Tribunal to inquire into the following:
(ii) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in Part Vc of the Bill is the most practical means of implementing a blank tape royalty scheme;
that is self-evident-

(iii) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in Part Vc of the Bill is the most effective blank tape royalty scheme for providing compensation to Australian performers whose material is recorded domestically on audio tapes in breach of copyright;

(iv) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzs (3) of the Bill for a statutory declaration entitling the purchaser of a blank audio tape to a refund of the royalty paid on that tape is the most effective means of effecting a refund or waiver of the royalty when the tape is not used for recording copyright material; and

(v) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzu (3) for the rules of the collecting society to make provision for the distribution of amounts collected by it is adequate to ensure that a reasonable proportion of the amounts collected is passed on or distributed to those whose own work has contributed to the making of the eligible sound recording or eligible work; and

That seems to us to be an eminently sensible proposition because there is no doubt that the Government has presented some legislation which has, I believe-and the Opposition believes-the right thrust, which is setting out on the right path. But we certainly remain unconvinced of the method by which the Government is seeking to achieve its objective. It is for those reasons that I strongly support the second reading amendment that the Opposition has moved. Nonetheless, I commend to the Senate the thrust of the rest of the Bill which I think does make appropriate amendments to the Copyright Act. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate. My response is rather long and I certainly will not be finished by 10.30 p.m. So much was said in the second reading debate that took place prior to our two-week adjournment that I thought it would be useful if I had a comprehensive reply prepared in relation to those matters that were raised, particularly by Senators Hill, Puplick and Macklin. In passing, I will be answering some of the matters that were raised by Senator Michael Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: Following introduction of the Copyright Amendment Bill and the Circuit Layouts Bill last November, there have been extensive discussions with affected interests, including educational institutions, broadcasters, the film industry, performers and copyright owners. As a result of these discussions, the Government will be moving amendments to the performers' protection provisions in the Copyright Amendment Bill to accommodate some of the concerns raised. In particular, concerns about the retrospective application of the provisions and the need for an `ephemeral synchronisation' exception will be dealt with.
Performers' Protection

Amendments of the performers' protection provisions beyond those proposed by the Government are not accepted on the basis that the regime in the Bill provides a workable framework for the exercise of performers' rights. Performers have not been granted a copyright. They have instead been granted real and effective rights enabling them to control the fixation of their performances and the subsequent use of their performances fixed on a sound-recording in the sound-track of a film. The Government does not wish to diminish in any way any of the rights granted under the Bill. To do so would effectively be to subsidise users of performances at the expense of performers.
Educational Copying

Section 53b of the Copyright Act allows educational institutions to copy copyright material if they keep copying records and pay royalties to copyright owners. Where copies are made by institutions for their correspondence students, other than as part of their lecture notes, no royalties are payable. Because of the acknowledged complexity of section 53b, the Bill will introduce a new, more streamlined educational copying scheme. It will not alter the extent of copying which can be done under section 53b but will afford institutions the opportunity to get right away from record-keeping by opting to pay copyright owners so much per student per annum for unlimited copying within the section 53b limits. It does not, however, continue the existing very limited right of institutions to royalty-free copying for correspondence students.

The Bill does, however, recognise the different needs of particular students by expressly allowing the Copyright Tribunal to set different rates for different classes of students, thus enabling institutions to argue for a lesser rate for correspondence students because of their greater reliance on print material.

The scheme in the Bill is the result of long and detailed consultations with educational and copyright interests and negotiations between those groups. The great majority of these interests, including schools, welcome the scheme on the basis that it will streamline and facilitate educational copying.

While recognising the special needs of institutions teaching correspondence students, the Government needs to consider the interests of both copyright owners and users in framing any exceptions to copyright owners' exclusive rights to exploit their works. It believes that the introduction of the optional new per-student royalty scheme represents a reasonable compromise between those competing interests.

The Opposition's proposal that the blank tape royalty scheme be referred to the Copyright Tribunal for consideration should be rejected. The scheme results from extensive, some might even say drawn out, consultations with industry and consumers undertaken over a number of years. Indeed, the possibility of a scheme was first canvassed in 1981 when the Attorney-General's Department undertook a review of audiovisual copyright law.

Several surveys have been undertaken, both here and overseas, to establish the extent of home-taping of recorded material. I believe that in Australia Reark Research Pty Ltd and Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd, commissioned by the Australian Record Industry Association, have undertaken such surveys. I think that answers, in part, the matter raised by Senator Michael Baume. These surveys show that between 80 per cent and 85 per cent of blank tapes sold are used to copy copyright material. For this reason, a number of countries, including France and Germany, have royalty schemes. Since the decision to implement the scheme was announced, the Government has had discussions with blank tape suppliers, who will be required to pay the royalty, in an effort to ensure that the mechanics of collection are as simple and cheap as possible.

As a result, details of the scheme's operation as first devised have been revised so as to significantly reduce compliance costs: there will be no requirement for special labelling of tapes on which the royalty has been paid; the royalty will be collected at the point of first sale in Australia-thus relatively few suppliers will be involved; and paperwork can be done once in respect of fairly large batches of tape. All costs of distributing the royalty to copyright owners will be borne by the collecting society, not the Government. Net proceeds of the royalty will go only to Australian copyright owners and those from the few foreign countries which operate an equivalent scheme under which Australian copyright owners are entitled to benefit.

Categories of beneficiary will include the owners of copyright in the music-that is, composers and lyricists; and the sound recording-that is, record and pre-recorded tape producers. Performers, while not copyright owners, will benefit indirectly under existing contracts which entitle them to at least 50 per cent of royalties received by record companies. The recording industry has undertaken that new contracts will provide-and those existing contracts which do not provide for the distribution of additional income under which the royalty would fall will be revised to provide-flow-on of the royalty to performers.

The collecting society and its rules require the approval of the Attorney-General. Provision is also made in the Bill to enable the making of regulations requiring the rules to contain specified provisions concerning distribution of amounts collected. The mechanism in the Bill enabling refunds of royalty to individuals is the most appropriate. The requirement to complete a statutory declaration deters abuse of the system while at the same time does not make it excessively difficult for genuine users to obtain refunds. In any case, it must be remembered in this context that institutions and other bodies using blank tapes for purposes which do not infringe copyright, for example, institutes for the blind, or which are licensed under separate arrangements with copyright owners, will be able to purchase tapes free of the royalty.

Any inquiry into the blank tape royalty scheme would be unlikely to raise issues not already canvassed and would seem inappropriate and certainly premature until the scheme has had a chance to operate for a period. In any event, conduct of such an inquiry is a totally inappropriate task to be assigned to the Copyright Tribunal whose function is to set royalty rates under various statutory licences in the Copyright Act.

In response to Senator Macklin's query about why the Government is not including videotapes in the blank tape royalty scheme, I make the point that the audio and video markets have different characteristics. The establishment of an audio royalty would not therefore necessarily constitute a precedent for a video royalty. In addition, video copying is generally done off-air for `time-shift' purposes. The material is usually viewed once only, at a more convenient time, fairly soon after the broadcast; copies are usually not kept and do not generally substitute for purchase. Furthermore, the video industry has not provided evidence or survey material of adverse impact on video sales of domestic video copying comparable to that provided by the recording industry in respect of audio material.
Media Monitoring

I note that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have foreshadowed amendments in relation to media-monitoring. The Government believes that the service provided by media monitors is certainly useful and worthwhile and should, as far as possible, be allowed to continue to operate. However, it does not believe that it is appropriate to legislate in this area at this time. This is a complex area where the relevant parties have for some time been endeavouring to negotiate voluntary licences. It seems that some headway is now being made, albeit through the pressure of litigation. Accordingly, it would be inappropriate to pre-empt a solution in this matter by legislating prematurely. In any case, the Government is not yet convinced that a free right in favour of media-monitors is the correct solution as such a right diminishes the interests of copyright owners whose material is being used. There are other possible solutions, such as a statutory licence, which should be explored should voluntarily licensing prove to be a failure.
Copyright-Design Interaction

Since the House of Representatives debate on the Bill the Government has received a number of submissions concerning clauses 9 and 10 which deal with the copyright-designs interaction. Having considered these submissions and the wide range of interests affected by the provisions, the Government is satisfied that the long overdue reforms introduced by clauses 9 and 10 represent the most appropriate balance achievable in this difficult area. The Government is confident that the principal objective of the provision, which is to remove existing uncertainties and inequities and to enhance copyright protection for artists and craftspeople, has been met. Moreover, an important Australian creator group is guaranteed copyright protection which previously has not always been available to it.

The Government welcomes the support by the Australian Democrats for clauses 9 and 10 in their present form. On the other hand, the Government rejects the Opposition's proposal to defer passage of clause 10 pending amendment of the designs legislation to cover designs which are presently unregistrable under that legislation. I indicate that the Government will accept the Australian Democrats' second reading amendment in a lightly modified form, not as to its substance.

The designs registration system under the Designs Act is one of the broadest in the world. Amendments of the Designs Act in 1981 had the effect of widening the potential operation of that Act and expanding the range of designs capable of registration. If a particular design for an industrial product does not meet the specified criteria for registration under that system, it is arguable that it is not appropriate that the product receive intellectual property protection at all.

The Opposition's proposal presupposes that amendments of the Designs Act to cover unregistrable designs will, in fact, be made. It is inappropriate to defer the operation of the Government's important and long overdue reforms of copyright law affecting designs, when the proposed Designs Act amendments may be found, upon closer examination, to be inappropriate. The Bill before the Senate deals with copyright-style protection which differs fundamentally from Designs Act protection. The copyright designs reforms stand alone and should not be prejudiced by any decisions the Government might make in relation to the Designs Act.

The Government also rejects the implication that the copyright-designs amendments will act as a disincentive to research and development. On the contrary, the removal of copyright protection for three-dimensional industrial articles will mean that manufacturers will be free to manufacture an article if, upon searching the appropriate industrial property register, the article is not covered by, for example, patents or designs protection. This will greatly benefit research and development of products in the manufacturing sector as a manufacturer will be free to manufacture an article without the risk that there may be in existence a design in which copyright subsists. This was an argument strongly supported by the 1973 Franki Committee which reported on the copyright-designs question. I should also make it clear at this time that the amendments being effected by clause 10 will only apply to the industrial application of designs which takes place on or after the commencement of the new section. The new section has no retrospective operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a few moments of the time of the Senate to pay tribute to Frank O'Keefe, the former member for Paterson, who passed away on 21 April, a few weeks ago. Frank was born in approximately 1912. In his time on this earth he gave great service to his country and to the people of Gunnedah.

SPEECH.PARA: I first got to know Frank in 1972 when I worked for him during an election campaign. I worked again for him in 1974, doorknocking in places such as Beresfield which is near Maitland at the southern end of the Paterson electorate. That was a very tough area for the National Party but an area in which Frank O'Keefe was very well respected. I was then campaign director for Frank O'Keefe in 1975, 1977, 1980 and 1983. In that period I worked for him for a total of six or seven months.

Frank was an outstanding politician in every sense of the word. He did what all politicians are supposed to do. He represented the voters without fear or favour and he considered all levels of people in his electorate. No matter who came into his office, he was always a perfect servant of the people. He was one of the most humble men I have ever met. His humbleness created an aura about him, but by no stretch of the imagination was he always humble. His character was very strong.

I always remember getting very concerned during campaigns because, at 9 o'clock of a morning, he would ring up his electorate office. I would say, `Frank, I want to get you on the road so that we can do some more doorknocking or visit some different people'. He would say, `David, just sit down there and wait for a short time while I make a few phone calls'. At 9 o'clock every morning he would ring up Paula Carlton, who is now electorate secretary for Eric Fitzgibbon, the honourable member for Hunter, and they would go through all the mail that had arrived that morning. I would say to him, `Frank, we should be out seeing a few people and doing a little electioneering'. He would say, `I must get all of those letters out to those people by lunch time today because if I do all those jobs for them they will tell everybody over the fence what a good job I am doing for them'. As I said, he was a consummate politician. He realised that, if he did a service for the people in the community, he would win their votes, and he did. In the first election, he scraped in with only a very small victory over the mayor of Maitland, and in later elections Frank increased his majority.

One interesting quirk about Frank was that always on the night before polling day he would find the person he was standing against and have a beer with him. That was quite an unusual thing for any politician to do, particularly after he had only just scraped in in his previous victory, whether it was over Noel Unicomb, Frank Murray or one of his other opponents. Frank was a man of great integrity and had a great feeling for the people he fought against in election campaigns.

Something else that comes to my mind when I think about Frank O'Keefe is his car driving. He had a little trouble with his eyesight in the early 1970s. He used to wonder why I would not drive with him to some of the meetings he had to go to. One of the reasons was that, because of his poor eyesight, he would line up an oncoming car and, at the last minute, swerve away. He always-or should I say in most cases-missed them, but he did have a little trouble with his eyesight when driving. He had his eyesight attended to and as I said, did not do any great disservice with his car driving.

He was a tireless worker for the Gunnedah district. He gave great service to local government. He was the mayor in 1948-49 and again from 1953 to 1969, a total of 17 years. He was an alderman from about 1944 to 1981. He was instrumental in setting up the Gunnedah abattoir and was its chairman from 1954 to 1969. He was appointed a member of the Order of Australia in 1979.

He had many great sporting achievements. He was always proud of the fact that in 1926 he won the 14 years 220 yards State championship in the Domain baths in Sydney. At 17 years of age he was playing first grade water polo and was a member of the North Bondi Surf Club. He was very proud of his swimming achievements and used to talk more of them than of his cricketing achievements, although if one got close to him at the Sydney Cricket Ground during a cricket test one would find he could probably bat as well as Bradman and bowl as well as O'Reilly. He was a solid middle order batsman-I am told a rather stodgy batsman-and a leg spin bowler. He was a member of the Gunnedah team of the present member for Castlereagh, Roger Wotton, which was regarded as king team of the north west. It was one of the best cricket teams ever to play in the north west. He was also manager of the Emu cricket team which went to Malaya. He put a lot of effort into cricket, especially as a member of the Sydney Cricket Ground Trust, of which he was a member for about 12 years.

It was only a few weeks ago that I was with Frank O'Keefe during a street walk in Gunnedah with Mr John Anderson. He was his usual self when I greeted him in his shop. I said, `How are you, Frank?'. He said, `All the better for seeing you'. It was always Frank's trait in life that he always made one feel very welcome wherever he was. He was in good spirits although he was not quite his usual self. However, he still displayed the Frank O'Keefe robustness and talked about politics and the good young man who would represent the area, and who spoke to the condolence motion in the other place this afternoon.

Another thing I would like to say about him is that he was a unstinting man. He had no family of his own but he had two nephews, Graham Curtis at Rowena and Don Pascoe, who ran the business in Gunnedah. Don played rugby league for New South Wales Country for four years. Honourable senators will probably remember his playing on the wing for Country. He also played for New South Wales for two years. Every morning during an election campaign Frank would ring Don to check how the business was going. That was the second phone call he always made before we went out on the campaign trail. I extend sympathy to Don and Graham and their families. To Frank's wonderful wife Nan, who gave him great support over the years, and her family, on behalf of the Senate and my family I extend the deepest sympathy and love. I know she will miss Frank as much as we will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to support the comments made by Senator Brownhill about the late Frank O'Keefe. I did not enjoy quite as long an association with Frank O'Keefe as was enjoyed by David Brownhill. I simply acknowledge all of the very positive qualities that Senator Brownhill has just put into the record. But I wish to speak because, on behalf of the Opposition I say to his widow, in particular, how highly Frank O'Keefe was valued in this Parliament. He was the antithesis of the caricature of a politician. All of the negative implications that there are in that word he lacked. He was a tremendously gentlemanly person and a very kind person. I know from my own visit to his electorate when I spent time with him when I was opening a nursing home at the time that I was Minister for Social Security, it was an absolute delight to be with him. Senator David Brownhill has very admirably sketched out why that would be so. That was the sort of man that he was. I can safely say on behalf of all Opposition senators that I extend to his widow our very great sorrow at his death and record the fact that we are very grateful for the contribution that he made in this place. He was in every sense a gentleman and he brought great credit to his profession of a politician. I am very sad that he has died. I am pleased that we have had this opportunity tonight to acknowledge his contribution both to this Parliament and to his immediate community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Brownhill and Senator Chaney in a very brief tribute to Frank O'Keefe with whom I served for eight years in the House of Representatives. Frank was as straight as a die, a totally honest, decent, honourable Australian who served his country not only in the Federal Parliament but also in the State Parliament of New South Wales, in local government and in other ventures, particularly the Gunnedah meatworks, run by his local council. In fact he served eight years in the New South Wales State Parliament, 15 years in Federal Parliament, 43 years in local government, 18 years as mayor and seven years as deputy mayor of Gunnedah. He went to Gunnedah in 1934-that is 55 years ago-with an oil company and then became certainly one of Gunnedah's greatest locals.

SPEECH.PARA: I first came across Frank O'Keefe when he was chairman of the Gunnedah abattoir which he had been a driving force in establishing in 1957. In those days, the Government created four country meatworks under the control of local government and, to my knowledge, Gunnedah is the only abattoir that remains under the control of a local body. Gunnedah meatworks was regarded certainly by far as the most efficient and best run country meatworks in New South Wales. This was in large part due to the chairmanship of that organisation by Frank O'Keefe. I was aware of that because I was a director of another meat company which used the Gunnedah meatworks as a processing point because it was unlike so many other council works in those days; it was efficient, well run and highly competent under his leadership.

I also came to know Frank O'Keefe very well when he was chairman of the Government's trade and resources committee during the Fraser Government and I was its secretary. We were together on some visits to remote parts of Australia. In particular, I fondly remember a visit to the north-western parts of Western Australia with Frank in, I think, 1979 when we all had the opportunity to enjoy his sense of humour and his great companionship.

In conclusion, I am glad that his contribution to Australia was recognised by his being made a member of the Order of Australia in 1979. He was Australian in every sense, a sportsman, a decent chap, a good bloke, a mate and, certainly, as a parliamentarian, I was very glad to have him both as a colleague and as a friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, join my colleagues in their expressions of sympathy to the late Frank O'Keefe's widow. When I first entered politics in 1983, Frank O'Keefe was serving his last term in the House of Representatives. I knew him there as a tremendous man who had a great personal following in his electorate. He was a man who was known far and wide. SPEECH.PARA: We have already heard that he was chairman of Gunnedah Municipal Council Abattoirs. TALK.START.PARA: —He left and then there was a redistribution.

—There was a redistribution and he probably did so to make a place for someone younger. That was the sort of man he was; he put other people before himself. I did not know him as well as my colleagues Senator Brownhill or Senator Michael Baume but I knew him for a short while. I thought he was a great guy, a great Australian and a great politician. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government in replying to the debate tonight, I join the Government in the sentiments expressed by Senator David Brownhill, Senator Fred Chaney, Senator Michael Baume and Senator Ron Boswell in paying tribute to Frank O'Keefe. I did not have the privilege or the honour of knowing Frank O'Keefe.
